big hop aroma -- a bit sugary , citric and piney . lots and lots going on just in the scent , and i can feel the back of my tongue tingling already .  the cascade hop explosion was still there , but i was able to handle it this time around and i really enjoyed it . ruby-amber color , bordering on red . awsome color .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and the carbonation is too light in my opinion .

this has got to be one the best smelling ipa 's out there . the fruity and hoppy flavours balance out perfectly to leave a tasty , dry , almost graperuit-esque finish which is just fantastic . this beer packs a mighty punch .  a . great appearance . 3+ fingers of super dense head . excellent retention . great appearance , lackluster smell , very interesting taste , good mouthfeel , drinkability good and overall uniqueness good .  m : medium body with a sticky quality when it enters the mouth .

this has to be one of the most interesting beers on the nose ~ lots of malty rye mixing it up with a bready note , lots of spice ( a mild chai cocktail - mostly clove ) , some green spruce notes ( probably juniper berries ) and gobs of orange and lemon zest . overall a beer that really smells great , tastes pretty good , and finishes nicely .  this beer looks great , clean and clear , good carbonation and head .  mf- raw resinous and sticky , becoming oily , medium carbonation , slightly astringent , dry and grainy in the finish d- well rounded ipa , but not the best around .

this smell is really on the money and superbly enjoyable . tasted honey sweet with dark malts and dark fruits that fades into a smoky birch bark and a really dirty lime or rhubarb sourness .  amazingly attractive .  this review is from notes in my `` travel journal . '' obviously the beer is now `` retired . there is some berry in the attack . the flavor smoothes out to leave a clean finish . it is a very drinkable beer , but not what i normally seek out .

bubblegum , banana and cloves . smells just like i 'd like a hefeweizen to smell . the taste does n't live up to the nose , however .  nice clear copper color with a decent tan head , nice active carbonation , and nice sheets of lace .  bought this over a month to two months a go and decided to give it a go . it is an ipa so it does have a nice bright orange to copper color . the taste and the smell are sweet and fruity , the only bad thing i have to to say about it , is the taste of tea is very lacking . i cant pick it up but , other than that i wish that stone , ishii and baird made this more as a yearly offering , cause its really good

the nose is incredible as it is with many of de dolle beers . big floral esters , mint , lemon , sweet malts and subtle but detectable hops . amazing brew , perfect for summertime , actually this is drinkable anytime ... beware of the burps !  one of the best looking beers . the cascade effect is great and the lasting tan head is inviting .  i think this batch was contaminated . so , this review only applies to the specific beer i drank . it had a floral hop finish . so , that extra ester punch made it deviate too much from the pale ale style . so i ca n't say i liked it , i 'd try again and find a better batch .

a- pours a light amber with a quickly dissipating head s- wow , this smells incredible ! it smells like cinnamon , nutmeg , graham cracker , pumpkin , and brown sugar . d- it 's highly drinkable , however the alcohol is not as well-hidden as in some other st imperials .  batch 265 a - pitch black body with a huge amount of coffee head that is frothy and sticks around s - chocolate cherries with some sour and funk laying around t - just like the nose .  m : dense and creamy with low carbonation .

s : smell is awesome . so complex for a stout which are normally one dimensional . coffee and dark unsweetened cocoa powder , whiskey/bourbon and even some woody notes that are muted .  pours an absolute black , that sucks light into it . rocky tan colored head emerges , disappates very slowly , and leaves nice lacing .  had to give it the maximum points for appearance , because even out of an imported bottle , it looks just right . comes in with an alcohol bite that 's almost like an imperial . pertty nice taste , though , and if you had some , i would n't refuse .

powerful , fresh hop scent , like being buried in bales of green leafy cones .  this beer pours a gorgeous clear deep orange amber color with a 3 finger ( on an easy pour ) of offwhite/tannish thick sudsy head . the head retention on this was ridiculous !  cons : the low carbonation level does hurt many factors of the beer , but it is such an exquisitely brewed offering , it 's only a minor issue .

it pours a cloudy golden orange color and smells delicious . the nose had hints of orange peel , coriander , hops and light caramel . drinkability was a little low though due to the over carbonation and the sweetness of the beer overall , but very good . will buy again  look is beautiful . perfect 1/2 inch head when poured carefully into a surly pint glass .  the mouthfeel is light carbonation , somewhat on the watery side , but very drinkable .

s - smell is terrific and pops way more than a lot of nitro beers i 've had .  they share the same appearance if poured into the same glass , and the head is excellent . the taste is almost identical , with the can version being perhaps a little more bitter . i think these nitro cans are a great invention .  m - a little strong on the carbonation for my taste .

the aroma is great . tons of grapefruit and orange . it 's perfect . wow it 's smooth .  750 ml bottle poured into a tulip glass . pours a cloudy corn silk hue with a pillowy cloudy white two finger head . super sticky on the sides with a head that sticks around forever .  very pleasant indeed . great hop character . this is a fairly balanced ipa . hard to say , it might just be because this particular bottle is more on the room temp side , but i would like more effervescence . a good beer all in all . i will be sure to drink it again , only a little colder and faster . more drinking , less typing ... .

sn consistantly produces beers w/ amazing hop boutique aromas . t - flavor profile pretty much mimics the nose w/ the malts and biscuit holding the fort down so the trademark sn cascades can do what they do best . mf - creamy , medium body and goes down w/ a slick and oily feel d - balance , balance , balance . highly sessionable .  a very nice brew that started with an absolutely great black color with an outstanding head and lacing .  m : thinner than i expected , pretty fair amount of carbonation , once again a little more reminiscent of a porter than a stout .

wow , one of the best smelling old ales i 've ever smelled . as it warms up so many different smells come out , yet it stays balanced . i thought this beer smelled amazing and was very complex and balanced . while the taste was a step down and a tiny disappointment after the smell , it was still very good . i thought it also had an amazing mouthfeel and while definitely a sipper , the abv is well hidden .  a beautiful appearance , two thick fingers of creamy light coco head with spectacular lacing coating the glass .  maybe a touch too much carbonation .

smell is of bourbon , wood , malt , brown sugar , toffee , and dark fruits . overall , this is a fantastic beer with very complex aromas and flavors . i am really glad i was able to try this one .  superb retention .  the mouthfeel is the only thing i think could be improved here and it very well may just be that i am having it from a growler .

great hop bouquet -- sweet and juicy , with citrus highlights laid over a smooth backbone of stonefruit ( mostly red ; think cherries , plums , grapes ) , and a little oak . i really like the aroma this beer puts out . the body of the beer is a lovely dark amber color that tinges toward straw around the edges of the glass .  as black as an overcast night in the woods with no light . thick creamy , milky , tan head .  this beer has a lot of flavor for a light . too bad its not a good flavor ! nothing impressive at all here . i 'm not sure what they are putting in this beer but its not worth the 7.99 they are charging for a six pack . i would recommend pabst blue ribbion over this any day !

another great beer from denmark , this little country is no slouch in craft beer world.poured into an imperial nonic a near jet black except from some chocolate brown highlights when held to the light , a large blooming lighter mocha colored head atop.to me the aromas couldnt get any better , a fantastic display of chocolate and resiny hop , maybe the best aroma of any stout i have come across , if you like the hops no matter the style its spot on.the mouthfeel is a little sharp and not as full on as i would have liked.bitter chocolate , dark fruit , and a healthy dose of resiny hop make for a well rounded flavor profile , if that mouthfeel was just a little more smooth ! a really good beer that is close to being great , love the hop play going on .  browning 's bourbon barrel imperial stout pours a very nice , pitch black into a snifter with a small , light tan head that leaves lots of lacing behing .  a light , medium in body . extremely active on the palate ; too carbonated , that really takes away from this hop-filled wheat 's pleasanty flavors .

it smelled of fresh lemon zest and pine and as it warmed i got notes of warm brown sugar , like fresh cookies which was most likely a result of the honey used in the brewing . the beer tasted very good , bitter but also smooth however the mouthfeel got a bit harsh nearing the end with the ethanol burn .  perfect looking .  not bad at all , really , although a bit thin for the most part .

what struck me first was the phenomenally fresh smell . the roasted malt and slightly bitter hops hits your nose and just stays there , begging you to take a sip . while the beer is great , the taste did n't quite live up to the smell . a bit thinner than expected and a bit less complex than i had hoped .  looks picture perfect . despite my allergies , i can actually smell floral hops .  mouthfeel was ok , not too thin , right amount of carbonation .

extremely fruit-fillled aromatics - pungent apple sauce notes lead the way into a more diverse array of stone-fruit esters . lush oaky notes with a touch of bergamot in the finish - complexity grows as the beer warms . i 'm still impressed that the base beer can be improved upon by soaking up the best characteristics of the barrels it is aged in , but these special editions of harvest ale have certainly `` matured '' more than simply `` aged .  pours with an excellent appearance , thick tan head with small dense bubbles and a clear hazelnut color .  the mouthfeel has a little bit more carbonation than i would like a brew of this calibre to have , thus the 3.0 .

with encouragement a dense coffee colored head towers , nice clumping froth . aroma is rich in complexity , airy dark fruits , grape , spices and fractal phenols . superb fairly low in sweetness which seems most pronounced in the finish . strong vinous notes with a dab of rum . tremendous complexity , warms wonderfully .  pours a pitch black color with a huge brown head into my glass .  as with several anchor offerings , i feel the carbonation is a bit overdone , but is n't powerful enough to be overly distracting .

aromas are fantastic ( pure wild ale ) . plenty of interesting aroma & flavor , and smooth going down .  750 ml bottle , procured at the pacific park market in aliso , a : pours a pretty much opaque burnt orange . huge frothy white head from the bottle conditioning , leaving lots of lace .  the taste is ok. it seems a little flat coming out of the can compared to the tap . nice clean finish , no lingering aftertaste . definiteley a session beer if drinking from the tap .

big sweet malty aroma . caramel , candied walnuts , raisins .  huge off-white head formed with large bubbles , eventually forming large craters in the top of the incredibly retentive head . as good of head retention as i 've ever seen . perfect dipa appearance .  pours a three finger light tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving a little lace . dark cloudy amber color . light carbonation and light bodied . caramel nose . starts balanced but then a caramel flavor that stays to a clean finish . a tasty wheat . $ 2.49 for a 500ml bottle from john 's grocery iowa city , ia .

one of the best smelling dipa 's i 've tried . nice dry finish . o a great dipa . enjoyed this beer very much . this is a hop monster with a nice sweet malt complimenting everything .  a : aggressive pour yields 1 finger of dark tan pillowy head with great retention .  t- roasty , sweet malts , coffee and dark chocolate m- starts off nice and creamy and full , then towards the middle loses a bit of it 's body and seems to get watery , only to return with a solid finish .

smells of strong peat , as you 'd expect with the name `` islay '' , but there is nice chocolate and roast balance . sweet flavour actually . very creamy mouthfeel , very sweet .  a : pours a cascading nitro-foamy head in a black background . the beer itself appears black at first blush , but upon close inspection is actually a very deep ruby/mahogany . it is a gorgeous beer .  m - the feel is not terrible .

s. plenty going on here in this one . d. a very good porter from left hand . the combination of aromas is brilliant . the taste is lighter than its 5.8 % abv .  a : deep brown with a nice fluffy tan head . 2-fingers to start , slowly receding . perfect .  had some fruity and clove flavors but was covered up due way too many hops for the style - not to mention that it was bitter . i barely finished it . other reviewers liked this beer and seemed to have a much different experience than i did which leaves me to believe that they have consistency problems or maybe they use different formulas for each location ? btw this one was sampled at the brewpub near the fleet center .

smells delicious and this scent would be a great air freshener .  the appearance is outstanding ! s : expresso like smell with subtle malty aroma .  i 've been waiting to try this one for some time now and it was well worththe wait ! i could smell it 's fruity aroma as soon as i opened the bottle , it has a nice dark cloudy amber color to it that is topped with a nice thick head . it goes down very smooth and just warms up your mouth , and you can really taste the spices in it .

aroma is wonderful . incredibly intense malt tones and a nice sweetness detected .  looks very lively . this looks amazing and out of control .  body is fairly thin , but that is expected for the modest abv .

looks find s- awesome citrus hop aroma , much more aggressive than i expected from a tiny , 4 % bitter . insane ! lovely m- body is overall pretty thin , nothing to see here o- awesome sessionable beer .  pours an absolutely gorgeous dark cola body that illuminates to a caramel-amber when held to the light . creamy , light tan bubbles form a sizable froth on top and slowly settle to a thick veil of foam , thanks in part to a vigorous carbonation level .  the mouthfeel seems a bit week and flat , but it 's not bad .

s : the nose is awesome . coffee . just so much going on .  12 oz bottle into pilsner glass a : beautiful ! crystal clear yellow body topped off by one inch of white creamy foam .  if i had to log a complaint , it would be that this stout is too thin and less of a cream offering . however , it is full of flavor and easy to drink despite being 6.5 % abv .

break out the smoked sausage , the perfect beer to accompany it is here . alaskan smoked porter is beautifully smokey . one whiff makes you think you 're in a great deli , loaded w/ good smoked sausage .  great `` belgian '' lacing & very good head retention smell : sourness & then woody , lactic notes .  the body was a bit too thin for my tastes in this style .

s - toffee , cocoa powder , nutty , then as it warms sweet citrus oil , green pine needles . slabs of caramel mix with alcohol vapors and fill the glass with a robust sweetness . t - starts with a mix of semi/sweet chocolate , sweet toffee malt , then an undertow of hops rush in with mint and citrus . the aroma is so good it 's hard to explain .  pours a fluffy , thick , white , three-fingered head , fades very slowly and leaves gobs of lace .  mouthfeel is a little on the thin side .

apricot golden body , tiny hop flecks visible and a classic ivory creamy , spritzy cap . the nose is very aromatic like a freshly prepped bowl of ambrosia . lots of ripe citrus in the nose , specifically tangerine and ruby red grapefruit . the taste is crisp , hoppy and i could tell upon first drink the mouthfeel is superb . i 'll say it , it 's overrated a little .  the geary 's hsa pours a beautiful dark amber , sticky-icky up the sides and a beautiful 1/4 inch head .  m : full bodied but way too over-carbonated .

smell : delicious and complex . truly a melange of different aromas . coffee bean , caramel , toffee , chocolate . wonderfully palatable . drinkability : very drinkable . excellent complexity of flavors .  what a great looking beer .  too much carbonation for this style ( -1.0 ) .

richer . the sweetness comes through much more . i highly recommend storing one of these away to turn a very good experience into a great one .  i enjoy just about everything this beer has to offer .  m-medium body and syrupy with a grainy tough texture . strong carbonation and a slightly messy carbonation in the finish .

the nose had a very fresh floral hop aroma .  a- deep , opaque brown/black . beautiful , rich , thick , deep dark tan head that lasts forever . even with an appropriate pour , the head was deeper than i 'd ever seen .  ; very sweet ( perhaps overly ) m : a bit syrupy overall , a fantastic barleywine style ale .

amazing . t : sweet malt that has plenty of peat flavors that i love so much in scottish ales .  pours the blackest black with no light coming through .  mouthfeel is medium with more carbonation that i expected due to no head showing up .

a : almost totally opaque , thin tan head that generates late and dissipates quickly , not much lacing s : smells like a campfire is the best way to put it , some light hops and malt , but mostly that charcoal mesquite , wow t : again , the campfire , but a little more subdued , some chocolate notes in the middle , with a hop bitterness in the back that mixes with the rough , almost metallic charcoal character m : pretty thick , coats the entire mouth and stays with you for a while d : a true sipper , amazing for the style , but it 's so intense , i had a little trouble finishing the bottle , one would be enough for me for quite a while  the head poured out at 1.5 fingers and stays that way forever in a rocky , creamy form that just refuses to recede . gorgeous appearance .  poured from bottle to tulip glass a : brilliantly clear pale yellow color with huge 3+ finger head that fades very slowly n : nose of a light belgian type wit with some light malts , touch of spices , toasted quality , touch of yeast t : starts with more malts and toasted quality , pretty light otherwise , a touch of light fruits and banana , slight earthy marzen quality , no spices m : very light and somewhat watery f : finishes dry and very crisp with a fading earthy marzen taste , would make a good session beer final thoughts : its a very light tasting oktoberfest/marzen .

this beer smells amazing . t : very roasty , lots of coffee , lots of chocolate , some sweetness in the background .  nice downward bubbles on pour ... dark brown to black with a slight ruby edge , a tan creamy nitro head , and lace like wallpaper .  bittersweet finish . kind of think and syrupy on the palate .

smell : smells like a nice rich coffee from sbux with tons of caramel added .  `` mad bitch '' has an great look . upon pouring it creates a beautiful white head that lasts for the duration of the drink . the beer is an opaque , honey color that is incredibly appetizing .  m - nothing special just went down really easy ... .it was n't bad tasting ... .i was surprised how quickly i finished it because it went down fast .

smell & gt ; sweet and resiny . a perfect balance of the two scents without much alcohol heat .  it pours clear ruddy amber with a very thick and creamy tan head .  a little more carbonation may have helped this one with its texture . just a tad thin , becoming a little dry but not crisp in the finish .

it was quite amazing . nice bitter coffee notes , with more chocolate notes and sweet malts than with the aroma . this was smelling great , drinking good and going down easy .  had great lacing and retention .  light in body and fairly thin on the tongue . smooth and lightly carbonated .

s : sweet dark frut nose come out followed by a chocolate toasted malt . on second whiff i am reminded of chocolate covered cheries .  bottle : poured a golden color ale with a huge pure white foamy head with great retention and lacing .  m : light-medium body with an oily mouthfeel , and a dry and resiny fade overall , not a bad beer , though it does stray from traditional belgian dubbels in a few aspects : not as sweet or yeasty as the classic belgian examples , a little hoppy for the style , and its too light .

excellent ! overall : amazing aroma , very complex and inviting , but i think it set me up for a super complex flavor profile that was n't there .  there is a magical cascading effect within the beer as it settles . a beautiful off white head remains perfect throughout the experience lacing is awesome .  wow this has to be one of the worst ideas in beer history . trying to cross a pale ale with a belgian and what you got is something that is a distant cousin to both . instead of leveraging the style 's strengths this beer doubles down on their worst attributes . a very hoppy tatse that fights like a strong ale . not a fun beer and a true shame that it might discredit weyerbacher 's other great beers .

the nose is extremely complex -- clay soil , caramel , butter , farmland , and fresh aromatic hops are all in there , along with some more elusive intangibles that are conjuring up all sorts of images of rural europe for me . on the tongue , the caramel sings out with a spritzy edge , the hops keep it interesting , and the butter moves to the forefront , but what really does it for me is a slight sour twist towards the end -- reminiscent of those flemish ales that ive recently fallen in love with ( such as duchesse de bourgogne ) . this says to me , `` drink with food !  found this one at julios randomly ... a : awesome look .  medium carbonation .

s : super hoppy . i love it . t : i 'm having trouble believing this is a barleywine . i know american bws are supposed to be hoppy but hot damn is this awesome . destroys your palate with an intense amount of hops .  appearance - pours with a nice , clear golden head , some dark reddish hues provide a little tint . two fingers of whity rocky head with a crusty top and lots of good stick .  light to medium bodied , carbonation seems to be at the right level .

exquisite nose has brandy , oak , vanilla , dark pitted fruits , candy malts , port wine and whiskey . taste does not hold the same complexity . some tart cherries , plums , caramel , toffee , wood , vanilla , wine grapes and cognac . past prime for sure , but still an interesting beer .  bottle poured into a pint glass appearance- beautiful ! one inch light tan head that slowly disappears .  lacks hops . lacks malt or any toasting . crisp , dry , clean , even a little bit bitter and metallic .

pretty tasty with a great aroma .  a- pours a splendid black color with a thin milky looking head that lasts the entirety of the beer and copious rings of lacing .  mouthfeel is a bit of a problem for me . the carbonation level is also a factor , making it hard to enjoy in gulps .

the smell is very potent . vanilla , cocoa , brown sugar , port wine . rich , sweet vanilla mixed with tart flavor that almost resembles a lambic ( kinda like ommegang 's three philosophers 2 % cherry lambic effects the overall pallet of that beer ) .  pours out like chocolate syrup , fills the glass pitch black with a very dark tan head . billowing foam despite a very cold serving temperature , thick chunks of lace , crazy retention .  m - a little thinner than i thought and more carbonated than i would expect .

s : the smell is quite amazing and complex in my opinion . there are some light hops initially noticed . overall , it is very pleasant . t : after the very satisfying smell , the taste was sort of a let down .  beautiful looking beer to be sure , dark , dark brown with a very attractive frothy tan head . just looks so good in the glass .  the taste is sweet and smooth , with a hint of hops but the most prevalent taste is of lemon . finishes with a very refreshing aftertaste . i would defiantly suggest this beer to even non craft beer drinkers .

s - bourbon , bourbon , bourbon , buttery toffee , roasted cashews , malted vanilla milkshake , tiny amount of hops , pecan pie , and harsh booze . this is the best smelling barleywine this nose has ever smelled . perfect . t - harsh and boozy , but delicious . caramelized sugar up front with tons of bourbon .  poured from the bottle into an oversized wine glass . a beautiful golden color with a fat head that loses size very quickly , but still sticks around some .  the body is is a serious letdown , nowhere near rich/full enough and it crosses the line into watery . the carbonation is appropriately subdued , and does n't overtake the lackluster body .

nose is fantastic - fruity and bitter , a bit earthy/grassy and just a tinge of honey sweetness ( think hopslam ) .  black with a nice brown head that leaves good lace rings .  mouthfeel is surprisingly light but overcarbonated .

as it warmed i started to swirl it and got a lot of booze in there too , which really added a nice touch . a lot of really good stuff going on here , but i find that with most iipa 's that , if they are using a huge amount of hops , they tend to smell better than they taste .  deep brown pour with a gigantic , rocky , tan head .  like drinking sour grass , probably the best way to put it m - low carbonation , slightly astringent d - not very drinakble , i had to leave a third of it

s - great hoppy but aromatic aroma with a warming malty finish . lovely hops they are using .  nitro-can encouraged frothy tan head , superb retention , some lace , almost opaque hue .  ) it has very low carbonation witch makes the mouthfell very average with about that of a tap bud lite , only a little tingle from the carbonation .

just flat out wonderful , this is just an exceptional nose here . the nose on this is just flat out fantastic .  12 oz bottle poured into an '08 osa pint appearance- pours a deep brown with a large dense tan head , sticks around forever . incredible head retention and lacing .  this beer poured a dirty blonde color , with a haziness that made me suspect that i would n't enjoy this beer too much . aroma was malty , and flavor was a sweet maltiness with only a hint of hops . this was n't what i was expecting from an american pale ale , and i really did n't enjoy it . i may have gotten an old beer , but there is no date code on this beer , so i have no way of knowing its age and it gets what it gets ... most of this one is going down the drain .

another cheer for this perfect blend .  this is a beautiful looking beer . not much lacing or retention , but the color alone gives this one a prefect appearance rating .  m - exceedingly bitter . needs to be a little creamier for this style d - not a session beer .

a- nice burnt orange coloring with a decent head and great lacing s- unbelievable aromas ... the tropical fruits are just amazing . you could mistake this for a glass of juice . t- kind of a letdown from the smell , but really the smell set the bar ridiculously high . this is definitely one of the better iipas i 've had the pleasure of tasting .  a : light orange color with the most insane head i 've ever seen . off white and very very creamy head .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and syrupy with a bit of sharp carbonation .

s : holy hops , batman ! intense , complex , and amazing . t : starts off with citrus and herbal hops , then transitions to a bit of caramel malt before finishing with a wave of piney bitterness . delicious . m : medium bodied with a good dose of initially spiky , finally smooth carbonation .  this beer is a handsome black with a pillowy light tan head that has great retention and lacing .  m : very thin mouthfeel however strong carbonation makes overall body light but full .

it smells awesome and makes my mouth water just anticipating the first taste !  the appearance is simply beautiful . a rich brown that seems to be characteristic of most trappist ales . this actually sort of reminds me of the way eku 28 eisbock smells , which is odd for a trappist .  it is a bit thin , bordering on watery with adequate to slightly low carbonation .

below average head retention , but the aroma more than makes up for a lackluster appearance as it brims with bold espresso and sweet chocolate notes . one of the best-smelling coffee beers i 've had recently , and the malt backbone is nothing to scoff at , either . overall , brewhouse coffee stout is amazingly aromatic , but could use a few tweaks here and there with regards to the appearance and mouthfeel .  a : forms a nice 1.5 finger frothy head in my sa perfect pint glass with very good retention . it 's a crystal clear beer with varying colors , being auburn orange at the thinner parts and ruby red at the thicker , and a good amount of bubbles floating up from the etch at the bottom . perfect appearance at least .  wtf did they do to this beer ? this is the first time i tried it since they put in the new brewhouse and i 'm not impressed . this used to be a wonderfully drinkable beer with orange and subtle spice flavors that made it quite refreshing . now its just overloaded with phenolics and all you can taste and smell is cloves . i ca n't get past the phenolic flavors enough to even finish a bottle . just horrible .

5.0 s : this is my absolute favorite type of dipa , i can tell already . it has a malt bill that can stand up to the hops in flavor and complexity . hops are citrusy with emphasis on orange and grapefruit . malts are full of caramel flavor and dark fruitiness like a barleywine . i did n't know what the hell i was tasting . the malts were a big disappointment as it was n't as complex as i would have liked . mainly just has the caramel flavor . 4.5 d : i would definitely like to have this been again , but not too often since it 's quite expensive .  appearance & gt ; looks like an giant-sized perfect pull of espresso .  tastes pretty amazing really . watery on the tongue but ends dryish .

the aroma is nothing short of amazing . it immediately presents with big raisin , molasses , strawberry , and bubblegum . i have had most of the unibroue beers , but this was really outstanding even for them .  light copper with a thick , mousse-like , sticky-as-hell head .  mouthfeel is just ok-nothing too incredible but quite drinkable especially at the 6.5 % abv .

the aroma was quite exceptional . never before have i whiffed this nose of smoke in a beer .  pours a vibrant amber with dark gold highlights and great head retention .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and somewhat tannic , but the overall effect is quite interesting .

very vibrant fruity/floral aroma with a hint of peat , grain and sweet caramel malt . all these blend perfectly together to make a fantastic aroma . certainly the best aspect of this beer . it tastes very much like the aroma - fruity berry , white grape flavors with a little herbal spiciness . the flavors are n't as rich as the aroma would suggest . a really nice beer overall . i genuinely enjoyed it , but i only with the flavors were richer .  a : beautiful head about 2 fingers thick that never goes below a half finger thick , ever . golden/amber in color , looks like honey . honestly , one of the best looking ipas ever .  m : medium to full body but needs more carbonation .

it reeks of pumpkin pie without being too aggressive with it . the pumpkin pie aroma does n't dominate the taste and it actually tastes like a beer instead of some kind of pumpkin pie flavored wine cooler .  on-tap at beachwood bbq , on to the beer : the head retention is great on top this coal black beer . great , thick lacing sticks to the glass .  i always drink my high life out of cans ! it looks like beer , smells like beer , and tastes like beer ... to keep it simple . this is my go-to macro , and will always be as long as miller keeps it the same ! prost !

smell : great aromas of licorice and chocolate . overall , the beer is a bit rough around the edges , perhaps from importation , but that is certainly part of its charm .  ( a ) - pours a clear golden yellow/orange color that produced a huge foamy/fluffy white head with great retention .  this beer is not awful but it is not good either . if use to be better , i think , back in the days before aluminum cans and pull up tabs . beer is fizzy and gives a good head and that is about the only good quality it has .

smell : the best part of this beer in my opinion . extremely complex ! i smell the chocolate and coffee but i am also overwhelmed by the super sweet heavenly smell of vanilla . taste : i was so happy that the taste was so refined , understated , elegant and smooth . drinkability : love it love it .  poured a slightly cloudy , amber to copper color with . nice frothy two finger off white lasting head . ample lacing cling to the glass .  the taste is very good , it could use a bit more body but the flavors are great . tons of chocolate and roastiness dominate the profile but there is also some caramel and hops . the bitterness is at a great level in comparison to the sweetness , especially for the style . the guy below me has it right : not quite edmund fitz or blake butte but this one is one of the supeb examples of the style .

s : smell is exceptional . tons of chocolate and brown sugar . o : a great smelling beer that just has too much alcohol taste for my palate .  pours a hazy golden color , with a huge fluffy white head . what a sight , as the head rose easily above the rim of the glass , and held there like an ice cream cone for a lengthy period of time .  picked up a few of these `` oil cans '' at a local liquor mart . this is the only place i 've seen them . i like the regular fosters occasionally , and have fond memories of it from various parties and times in life . after looking at the color , noticed that the can said `` caramel coloring added , '' so nothing real to go by there . i liked this , i guess , but the drinkablility was hampered by a fakey sort of bitterness that did n't hold a candle to the fuller 's and young 's of the world . kind of caught in my throat . i pick up the regular if it 's on special , but for a real bitter , this ai n't it .

the smell is wonderful . tannin , grapes , apples , apple peels , raisins , caramel , touch of cocoa , and a hint of alcohol .  a- pours dark black . one of the prettiest beers i 've seen .  m : a bit light in the mouth , but it kind of coats your mouth as well .

smell only needs one word : raspberries . lots of raspberries . also smells a bit tart and kind of like juice . very sweet and tart at the same time .  just an over-sized glass with great markings . excellent to look at . a clear golden pour with a very generous head .  ambrosial start , lots of malt , the top skimpy in feel with the finish having a delightful hop spicy bite , the carbonation moderate and the aftertaste droughty and long lasting .

aroma smacks you . good and hard . hops and oak would be an obvious statement . my notes indicate an amazing floral and woody perfume aroma . initial flavor is upfront pine and sweetness .  ) pours a beautiful glowing , hazy , golden color . really gorgeous and appealing appearance .  reminded me a bit of bmc with a bit of syrup added for sweetness . the taste is more of the same with a quick malty dryness at the end that seems to say , `` ha ! had you fooled..you thought there was about to be something pleasant here , did n't you ? in fact , this may get sacrificed to the kitchen sink . as i always say , in total fairness to the brewer and his ( or her ) intentions , this may have its fans , but it most assuredly is *not* for me ...

there is a lot to this scent , but it is surprisingly balanced , pungent sweetness and hops with subtle funk . good stuff , but it 's a shame it does n't match the glorious scent . mouthfeel is medium bodied and smooth , but a bit watery .  excellent lacing . great looking ipa .  mouf & gt ; easy , average .

the smell is exceptional . it smells like candy the mouthfeel is really smooth , and not very thick .  appearance : pours a motor oil black with a 1 finger creamy milk chocolate brown head . excellent lacing . like all the other yetis , this one looks perfect .  the body of the beer is actually approaching medium and the carbonation is not overly fizzy as many macros are .

at long last i was finally able to snag the great westy 12 , pours a deep brown with a suprisingly thin head that was gone pretty quickly not leaving anything behind.whoa the aromas are just incredibly complex and rich , some almond and raisin almost a cinnamon bun type aroma to it , just awesome.flavors are more mellow than expected , i get some star anice and raisin up front with some mellow orange tinge in the lngering finish.i like the `` 12 '' better than the `` 8 '' but i have had some better quads but still a pleasure to drink for sure .  a quick swirl brings nice crimson flashes to the glass , quite amazing ... the aroma flows to my nostrils from feet away .  my first taste of it was great , however it lacks in the balance of the malts , and has sort of a over roasted taste . altogether though , this beer in my opinion is the best of the coors brand and i would recommend for something new . not a everyday beer though .

very very nice . very complex .  presentation : it was served in a tulip glass from tap at the pizza plant italian pub . appearance : looking into the glass it had a deep reddish brown colored body with a creamy light tan head . the head was long lasting , thick and it left tons of sticky lacing to cling to the sides of the glass in thick rings . ( very impressive ) smell : the aroma hits first with a bit of boozy alcohol .  there was a very light mouthfeel , but an extremely dry , crisp finish .

perfect fruit scent . clean , pleasant , and wonderful . almost erotic , even - i want this beer to have my abortion .  bottled 10/31/11 a : pours jet black with a nice finger high layer of dark mocha head that laces the glass nicely .  m-medium carbonation . medium body , slick .

smell was out of this world . very fresh hop smell , got me all excited about the fist sip , but ... taste was very underwhelming .  appearance : pours an off-white , two-finger head with good retention . even , abundant lace left on glass .  the mouthfeel is a little lacking in carbonation too .

aroma is just perfect . a slice of pumpkin pie in a bottle is what this beer is . picture perfect . easy to drink with good mouthfeel .  the body is as dark as night ; it is absolutely impervious to any light .  mouthfeel is okay , no carbonation to speak of .

head stays for a good while s- smells identical to apple pie .  poured a translucent mustard/straw yellow with a huge , rocky , white head that faded into clumps of white froth . beautiful lacing .  mouth feel : a bit thin on the palet , or maybe the aroma and taste make you expect more in the way of mouth feel .

the smell is utterly fantastic , easily one of the best smelling beers i 've ever come across .  a : very good looking brew - copper/red clear body with white head .  it must be said that this beer is a bit astringent on the palate and a bit thinner than i would have liked , but it is still rather drinkable .

smell : sweet citrus hops that smell incredibly fresh . the sweet malt balances things out well , but still lets the hops shine . overall : this beer smells awesome and the taste is a bit of a letdown . that being said , it was still quite good and i would have another .  a : pours absolutely perfect ! cloudy , creamy orange body with a glorious mountain of head that fills just to the edge of the glass and hangs around until the glass is empty .  mouth feel is thin pretty characteristic of bbc 's beers which makes this a really drinkable session stout with a lot of flavor .

smell : this is one of the most complex aromas i 've ever come across . what first appears mildly hoppy explodes into a crazy , fruity , tangy aroma of raspberries , currants , candy sugar , caramel malt , and a number of other notes that i could n't place my finger on . taste : almost underwhelming after the fantastic aroma , but lives up to the hype . alcohol also has a presence here with a slight burn on the midpalate , but actually kind of pleasant . surprisingly subdued and also very smooth . mouthfeel : velvet smooth and full bodied as it just slides down the back of the throat .  appearance this beer is absolutely gorgeous . the body is a dark , orangish-brown and murky with lots of carbonation and had a bountiful , brownish-white head that was full without exploding and pitted well on top of the liquid leaving some awesome , shaving cream foam around the edges of my pint glass .  a rather thin aqueous body with less carbonation than expected , but otherwise nothing wrong with this brew .

that settles into a nice thick lace covering most of the glass yes it 's a chocolate stout and the aromas defiantly back it up lots of sweet chocolate aromas some earthiness to it along with some hint of roasted malts flavor 's of dark chocolate are dominate not overly sweet with a coffee backbone it 's got this mocha thing going on the mouthfeel is medium to thin would have liked it a little thicker this is really one of the great chocolate stout 's especially for under $ 5 a bomber well worth the experience  a - black as night with a thick frothy brown head . fades slowly leaving a thin solid layer of foam on the beer with excellent lacing .  the mouth was a bit oily but not unpleasantly so .

crazy amount of hops , smells awesome . t - tastes of citrus hops , pine , grapefruit , smooth fruity malts . d - this is definitely a very good black ipa .  the appearance was outsatnding ... a creamy head that lasts forever with a beautiful cascading efffect ... almost pitch black in appearance .  it is slightly watery on the palate .

s : sour cherries are noticeable before the glass reaches my nose . t : the aroma carries well into the taste as the sour dark cherry hits the palate first and then gives way to the sweetness which tastes more like a jolly rancher than sweet tart .  this one is jet black with an enormous off white / light tan head . this head is quite frothy and laces incredibly .  m : starts off creamy , but i 'm pretty quickly struck by how watery this is . the carbonation is decent , but i find this surprisingly thin .

buttery , pure milk chocolate sweetness hits the nose at first , then is ceded by notes of carob and suggestions of chocolate covered candied orange peel along with coffeeish , borderline burnt roasted barley . real chocolate never wavers in aroma , remaining constant and assertive .  pours a completely opaque pitch black . light brown head with some big bubbles around the edges .  m : fairly thick , carbonation seems a tad high .

smell is the leader of the pack , amazing scent of coffee , cream , smoke . drinkability suffers from the mouthfeel since this is the only non style rating , but i really like this porter .  perfect head retention and plenty of lacing left behind in the glass .  mouthfeel is ok , but too watery and thin feeling for my tastes . drinkability is quite good , the only real flaw i found was the weak mouthfeel .

the smell is strong of both a carmel brandy and a little alcohol is evident . the alcohol that was apparent in the scent is not in the mouthfeel , which is very nice .  pours a deep , opaque mahogany , almost black . there 's a 3-finger cafe au lait head with a moderate amount of layered lacing .  mouthfeel : high carbonation gives the impression of a thinner mouthfeel , and the carbonic acid and alcohol bite knock this one down a little in the mouthfeel rating .

smell - smells absolutely delicious ! ! lots of fruit/wheat and some toasty nuts ... yumm , 5 for sure .  the white head is huge and pillowy and leaves wonderful fuzzy navel lacing .  a-garnet with small ring of foam s-raisin , pancake syrup , faint vinager t-assertive sour front , sour cherry , some malt sweetness , dates m-medium , with average carbonation d-very tasty !

the aroma , which was really the high point of this beer , was quite terrific -- roasty malt with hints of chocolate and black cherries .  it pours a dark brown to almos black color with a huge fluffy tan to light brown head .  under carbonated .

the smell was slightly chocolate . 2007 bottle 02/23/2008 beautiful smell like gourmet chocolates , an amazing improvement over the last year . this beer is a really good example of a cellar-worthy beer . 2006 vintage 01/10/09 smells malty grains , some chocolate , tastes good and probably ca n't get much better .  pours vibrant pale gold with lively streams of carbonation sustaining an impressive large white head and leaivng lovely lacing .  not too many micro 's that come out with a light ale . hats off to them for bringing this to market to allow folks who are used to drinking american mass producted swill to move into a easy drinking michigan micro brew . lighter than sam adams but more flavor then the bud and miller 's of the world .

overall a fantastic beer .  the pour is beautiful . intense rich brown/black , with a two finger dark brown head .  the beer really lacks in body . carbonation is great . overall this was a good beer but the body creates a void .

smells fucking amazing . this is the best-smelling beer i 've ever had . it smells like exotic , spiced , fresh-roasted coffee , like you 're standing in [ trendy east side coffee shop ] . really good , but not quite on the same transcendent level as the nose .  pours deep red , with some f*ing amazing head on it .  taste/mouthfeel : this beer is slightly oily , with a very limited carbonation .

smell- the smell is another one of my favorite parts about it . i can smell mangos i think . taste- ok at first it is a little bitter but once it settles it has a great full flavor tast to it .  enough of the stupid remark , bust out the old guardian glass and opener and get on to the beer : it 's magnificent looking ; a darker shade of gold , tiny bubbles that are clearly visible from a few feet away , a thick creamy top that seems to last forever .  the mouthfeel is thiner but still good .

the smell is very strong of nutmeg , cinnamon , pumpkin . this is an excellent pumpkin ale . the scent is so strong you will convince yourself that a pumpkin pie is baking nearby .  pours a coal black beer with a good reddish brown head .  a wonderful beer . one i have had before , and thought it would be great for the new year . it 's dark brown hue and brownish colored head was delightful . the taste of cocoa and hops pleased my nose . the roasted flavors were soothing , but left a little bit of an after taste .

sour raspberries + classic cantillon funk = awesome . i love it . t : raspberry essence jumps into my palate and my nose as i raise the glass , and as soon as the beer hits my tongue the fruit gets displaced by intense sourness + moderate cantillon funk . delightful . o : i expect every cantillon i drink to be amazing , but based on other reviews i really was n't hoping for anything special from the framboise .  ths one poured a dream , you shoulda seen it , looked like a photo from a beer book . billowy head sticking out of the glass all proud and boastful , very cool .  light copper color with a large head s. malty with a slight resiny hop smell t. more bitter than sweet but well balanced with roasted malt m. a little to acidic and carbonated for my tastes d. a good lighter amber ale that i can heartily recommend

s : about what you 'd expect from an ipa- flowery , with lots of citrus . i 'm detecting lemon , melon , and other tropical fruits . i 'm used to lemony scents from ipas , but this one has something different- it 's the distinct melon i 'm getting from the nose . t : very `` clean '' tasting , lots of citrus at the beginning . the ending is quite bitter , but not a much as some ipa 's i 've tried .  best before 26.09.05 appearance : awesome . poured with a nice long lasting beige head .  mouthfeel is very dry with almost no carbonation .

smell is on the sweet side but hoppy as well , sweet bubblegum scent , weed , juicy citrus and a malt punch , great scent . taste is enjoyable , alot of different things balancing sweet and hoppy in that order with the above mentioned scents going into the taste without the weed .  poured a deep , uber cloudy orangish color with good carbonation leaving a nice white cap s : loads of faded hops , fruits..apricot and others with booze t : big faded hops powered by fruitiness and booze .  cake/nutty malt up front with a huge , thick spiced tea hop flavor headbutt with the swallow . not just season 's best , but saranac 's best . i usually find them to be just an average brewery but this stuff is nice .

this is quite possibly the sweetest smelling beer i 've ever sniffed .  appearance : the brown head that just will not die . halfway through the glass i 'm still looking at a thick 1/4 ince layer of foam . there 's dried up , sticky lacing all over the glass , too . a perfectly dark taste for a dark brew .  mouthfeel is a bit thin .

an immense hop punch to the nose . extremely fresh , bitter hops practically leap out of the glass . further in i get notes of orange and citrus , wrapped into a pleasing sweet malty undercurrent . superb nose . t. alas , after such a superlative smell , how could the taste hold up ? it 's a fantastic smelling , `` lite '' double ipa that is easy to put down .  a- pours a brownish color with red hues noted against a white background . the clear nature of the beer allows me to see the carbonation , which is modest looking at best . the head is plentiful and puffy looking , retaining well and leaving behind a thick film of dense foam on the glass .  m- smooth , but a tad thin . carbonation is good , as is the thoroughly smooth finish with a tad of warmth .

it 's a good inviting smell .  pours a viscous black and creates a textbook appearance for the style .  m - a little thinner than i imagined , though based on the aroma , i might have been expecting a double ipa .

subsequent sips bring forth strong chocolate notes mixed with a nice bitterness.the aroma a each sip is truly fantastic . finished nice and creamy with a strong bitter note present .  ahh , maudite . a beautiful beer from a beautiful brewery . pours a dark , stained oak or cherry colour . nice , 2 1/2 finger froth head that clings to the glass .  incredibly light with cereal grains , very grainy taste , hops are nowhere in site . there are way better summer beers out there .

smells delicious . sweet raisin and toffee come through very clearly .  reviewed 1/8/2008 ( bottle ) : pours a golden somewhat cloudy yellowish color . big foamy frothy white head with good lacing .  i always look forward like most do the annual stone anniversary brews.poured a rich deep amber with a tight and sticky one finger off white head , big hops in the nose with a mix pine and herbal/leaf , there is a gummy , fruity-like sweet note as well.the mouthfeel is a bit sharp i will say it crashes down the gullett at first , it does begin to smooth out after a few sips but still seems a bit harsh.no holds barred hops hit the palate up front with big pine and big herbalness , a healthy does of sweeter alcohol gives a slight burn along with a bit of dark fruit.very good but seems like it something that should sit for awhile , still another fine one from stone .

things are looking good , very good t : a little bland at the front but it builds slowly with some nice coffee and chocolate flavors .  a massive , three-inch head rose up to the top of the tulip glass . lacework aplenty . a real beauty .  mouthfeel is way more thin than the head and lacing made me think it would be . very quaffable .

just great . t : similar to the smell but with bit of smokiness .  poured out of a 16.9 oz bottle into a tulip style glass . i held it up to the sun on my patio and admired it for a few seconds . ( cue music ) there were two inches of white head that led to a nice white cap that never dissipated .  just some `` laying down '' advice : had the extreme plesure of six-year bottle conditioning tasteing , in which years 4-5 were exceptionally good . year 3 was quite good , with anything under that seemingly `` young '' tasting . after year 5 the qualities that make it a stellar barley wine were fading .

s : the smell is very balanced and i am loving it . mild fruity esters mix with sweet bourbon , vanilla , and coconut to form what is probably the best smelling beer ( non-ipa ) i 've had before . d : fantastic barrel aged barleywine . great job mayflower .  it poured with a big , long lasting , and super stiff foamy cap .  mouthfeel is soft and a little heavy .

this notes of grapefruit and pineapple . just thick hop notes here so ripe and fresh it was like heaven just smelling this . smooth and mellow delivery of the flavor , though not as strong as the aroma would have led me to believe . light alcohol notes as well and a really good medium feel to it . something i would love to try again as the aroma itself was worth the price . this was damn nice  pours a dark reddish brown with a huge off white head with huge fat lacing .  perhaps another way to explain the feeling would be a textured shandy . noting the high praise this saison received , i have trouble fathoming such a bad experience .

smell- figs ! drinkability- deciptively drinkable , i could finish up this bottle in a hurry and then find out that it 's 10 % abv afterward . nice .  sticky lacing all the way up the glass , and infinite retention on the eventually short head .  4/5 m : surprisingly thin side of medium , slightly tongue numbing , spritzy .

the beer smells or peat and smoke with a hint of chocolate and molasses . it tastes and smells delicious and really is a good example of a scotish ale .  a- glourious golden yellow with a fluffy and foamy white head that retains well in the tulip glass . dies to a fluffy ring and nice cloud that leaves thick lace all along the glass .  nice carbonation , but this comes off as a little thin . this should be more drinkable considering its thin body , but as this is a stout , the thin body is a bit of a turn off .

the smell is very fresh , crisp and clean ; truly wonderful . lots of citrus and pine aroma coming off immediately , mostly grapefruit with some floral grassiness as well , with some biscuity malt in the background . i could smell this a mile away and loved it . t : taste follows nose for the most part , leading off with citrus-pine hops with a sweet biscuity background . it 's fairly bitter , but the malt sweetness balances it just enough to keep it extremely pleasant and crisp . the taste was very fresh and very clean , ending as it began with a gentle , bitter , floral hop bite . the smell is exquisite , and the taste is juicy and not as dry as many similarly citrusy-bitter ipas , making it a bit more drinkable . with all the smaller breweries popping up in boston , and many focusing on more boutique styles , it 's great to see a new , local ipa that seems to be doing everything right without reinventing the wheel .  really beautiful beer , pours a hazy golden color with a huge frothy white head that retains impressively and leaves nice lacing .  m : the thinnest , lightest imperial i can remember , but the intensity doesnt have to be overpowering .

2008 vintage a- almost stout-like in appearance , no head , fizzy swirl of carb in the middle of a color-devoid structure ... s-vanilla , cherry , oak , intense , strong , amazing smells ... .omg ... .there is n't a single hint of sour beer behind this nose . simply smooth vanilla and cherry ... awesome ... .ca n't remember a better nose on a sour ... . t- starts off smooth , nothing much going on *served at 39 degrees f.* then spice , phenols , tartness , tanginess , oh man ... this is great ... . m- solid brick of a mouthfeel , with a few glimmers of carbonation ... nothing exceptionally nasty about the 'brick ' that i speak of , but it is different ... .all together a different beer but for mouthfeel , i 'd expect something flat to taste like this , but in all it provides the right amount of carbonation ! duchesse on crack ...  it pours a decently frothy tan colored head .  flavour is better than expected- a little woody and slightly spicy , with a thick strong maltiness . i 'd like the hearty body on this one , were it not for the turbocharged carbonation .

aroma is exceptional , with a great sweet citrus smell that bursts from the bottle and makes you want to take a huge gulp . this is n't a horrible beer , and if you love bitterness , you should love it .  this is the dead-on look for a pilsner ; pale straw color with steady streams of bubbles heading for the surface . the head is huge and sticky and clings to the side of the glass as if it were a life-or-death matter .  do n't brewers taste the beers they brew after they 're done ? how many sips does it take to get stone juxtaposition to the center of my sink drain ? i think this beer is really spent burnt coffee grounds blended with colgate toothpaste in a bottle .

smell is phenomenal ; coffee , mocha , vanilla , kahlua , coffee cake ... the aroma is outstanding . perhaps the best porter i 've ever sniffed . this beer is simply delicious . slight let down from that a+ aroma but minimal . tastes like the smell but with some malt and roasty notes . very drinkable .  a : pitch black , slightly viscous . excellent head formation and nice lacing . this is how an ais should look in the glass .  a touch lightly bodied , with an oily , but thinnish and passably dextrinous mouthfeel .

smells great ( but nothing like a gumball imo ) . incredible . very bitter for a pale ale , or pale wheat ale , whatever . it certainly smelled good , but nothing more than the typical tropical fruit-heavy pale/ipa .  poured out of the bottle into my samuel smith 's pint glass a jet black in color with a nice 2 finger tannish-brown head that settled to about one finger after a few minutes .  thanks walter a-a nice rich amber , good head , some lacing that turned into a small bubble ring s-a slight bready smell , some citrus ( makes me think of citra hop ) slight sweetness and then tart t- close to the same as the smell , there is a slight tangyness in the middle of the drink , it 's a good thing m- it 's moderately lively not as much bite and tingle i was expecting , a clean wet finish o/d- overall i really like this , it 's not the craziest ipa but it 's more than just decent , drinkability , i can see myself finishing this growler , this is a tasty beer and one i really like

the smell is quite pungent . i can smell the glass from a foot away ! sweet caramel malts are picked up in the nose , but are nothing in comparision to the huge hops assault . it is very hop foward ( understatement ) . this is easily one of the most unique and bitter beers i have ever had . the hops oils make it quite slippery and oily going down .  pours a cloudy amber brown into a wine glass with two fingers worth of frothy , white head . the lacing clings to the inside of the glass for dear life , and is quite exquisite .  an american classic . good fall back beer , or one to enjoy when a less complex brew is desired .

dipas aroma 's are awesomely hard to describe .  poured into a pint glass , this turned out to be a really beautiful beer . it was an amber color with a thick off-white head that persisted throughout the time it took me to drink the beer . there was an amazing amount of lacing .  the carbonation and the color were good , but this did n't make up for the off taste and smell .

smell : ah ... it 's been a while since i smelled something so interesting , so refreshing . sour concord grape juice , light farmy funk , an undercurrent of yogurty lactic tang , nutty sherry , and oaky port . really , a great nose . taste : sour through-and-through , with a spicy , envigorating tartness that swells in intensity as you hold it on your palate , then dissipates slightly before a clean , bracingly tart finish . very good , very bright , and very refreshing , but i do wish there were a bit more depth in the malt profile . this is exceptionally flavorful , interesting , and drinkable , especially at only 6 % abv .  $ 5.00 / 750ml bottle county market grocery store stevens point , wisconsin appearance - a haze of golden yellow to a pale orange with a lasting frothy white head . very much carbonated as a constant flow of tiny bubbles speed to the top if the beer from the side and bottom of the pint glass .  the mouthfeel is light , but hey , its a light beer ! for drinkability , again , one of the beers that could probably never offend me .

the aroma is a very nice rich creamy milk chocolate . the best part of this beer is that the aroma is so strong , it is a major component of the beer even while drinking the last swallow . nice feeling coming out of a bottle .  a - pours black with a nice light-tan head . looks great . sticks fairly well to the side , just about as good as a porter could .  remarkably good . but pay attention : almost 10 % alcohol , but you hardly remark it . it does not have that much body , but it surely has a delicate taste . i 'm a bit more inclined for brown beers , but this one is really good , and not brown at all .

overwhelmingly the finest ipa i 've ever sniffed . perfect . m - very good . nice carbonation and appropriate chewiness without being syrupy .  pours with a vast amount of co2 . produces a beautiful light tan head that sticks around forever . the body is dark amner in color .  lowish carbonation and a light , smooth mouthfeel .

wow , the smell is the absolute best part of this brew - strong on the citrus . when first tasting dreadnaught , i picked up more piney hop taste than the smell indicates . the more i drank , however , the citrus hop flavor came through . i paid $ 8.99 for this bomber and it was worth it ( although pricey for an everyday beer ) .  a : pours a vigorous 4 finger creamy white head with excellent retention . lacing is amazing considering the light body , with layers clinging to the side of the glass like a ruler .  m : very carbonated .

the aromas promise a dandy ; juicy dark fruit ester , roasted coffee , pineapple , chocolate powder and molasses , and hints of bubble gum . a silky mouthfeel , slightly oily , and a sharp carbonation that does n't bite too hard is quite enjoyable . dark fruits , plum , sweet tobacco notes and some coffee and cocoa but not like the nose indicated .  excited to try this one ... a : looks perfect . deep murky copper color with a thick 1 inch white head that fades decently .  smooth mouthfeel with a moderate amount of carbonation and just a little watery in the finish .

s- strong aroma of banana , clove , yeast , pear , bubblegum , wheat , nuttiness , and spice . complex and aromatic . t- banana , clove , pear , lots of spice , and the alcohol was surprisingly prominent , some warming . m- pretty high carbonation , crisp , finishes dry , drinks smooth o- first weizenbock i have ever had .  the imperial stout was very black in color with a dark brown head . very pretty .  it is a little light in body but i 've noticed that porters and stouts are generally lighter from a can .

a truly profound smell . has all the plums and figs of a dickens novel .  appearance- pours a crystal clear brownish red , almost cognac , with four fingers of beautifully structured soapy bubbles . the head peaks well above the rim of my glass , and compacts to a creamy , hefeweizen-like consistency . outstanding lacing leaves sheets behind . excellent .  had this on tap when i was being introduced to the lager style of beer . it 's smell is very specific to the beer and is appealing if you are craving a medium-bodied lager . its has a malty intake and a bit of a spicy , hoppy after taste . it goes down smoothly but the taste tends to stick around and interfere with ordered food . it is very drinkable but as stated , but be careful when drinking this with food .

amazing , both the most unique and best smell i have in a beer in a good long time . taste- a strong and front malt body .  very pretty two-finger head .  mouthfeel : heavy , chewy , slick , low carbonation borders on flat .

the smell was magnificent , and like i said i wish it had been in a snifter to catch more of these floral and citrusy aromas . outstanding .  i 'm very impressed with this beers look .  heavy mouthfeel .

the smell is outstanding - i was salivating from the roasty nutty goodness .  dark mahogany color with a 1 finger , light tan head with excellent retention and lacing .  taste some roasted chocolate flavors . flavor lingers on the tongue after each sip . not quite what i would consider a savoring beer , but tasty none the less . i could drink this beer around the fire in the winter or after raking leaves in the fall .

s- super hoppy and sweet with a mixture of predominant pine flavor and underlying grapefruit notes ... absolutely exquisite . t- taste is very reminiscent of pliny the elder but possibly better balanced .  a : orange colour and a huge 4 cm head that sticks around due to the high carbonation .  feel is a bit coarse , but just a bit .

the smell- incredible . at first , very sweet smelling- hints of pineapple . for such a strong beer , it finishes very abruptly , leaving you with just a tad of malt . overall , incredible .  this is a great looking beer , more black than brown and , when held up to the light , a beautiful red highlight appears .  nice aroma of hops but i would hope for a bit more being a hops lover . the celebration ale , from the same company , seems to hit the spot more than this beer but still worthy of a place in the fridge and still better than many micro beer ipa ii . sierra nevada seems to me to be the only mass beer company that brews excellent beer for `` mass beer '' prices .

m- thick and oily , slick and refreshing . d- very tart and complex flavor combination of hops .  pours a pitch black color with a two-finger head that fades down to some lacing . good color for the style .  carbonation is fizzy on the tongue where it should be soft and creamy .

a truly wonderful bouquet . taste accents of hops and light fruits , again pineapple , with a delayed afterthought of hops bitterness at the back of the throat . a tasty and sexy organic brew .  this beer was poured a very dark rich chocolate brown with a thin tan head . with this beer being pushed nitrogen , it had a ton of lacing and the head lasted the entire beer .  mouthfeel was somewhat on the thin side , but still quite acceptable .

scents i can pick up are grain , oats , cream , irish dry stout-esque . there is also some sour and hop notes . i reckon this is probably the epitome of an oatmeal stout .  excessive packaging ... appearance : pours a thick , gloupy black and then cascades out an amazing amount of dark tan head that haves great retention and is very creamy looking .  finishes dry with nice mocha notes & a touch of charred grain mf : very oily & smooth as all hell with low carbonation & nice stickyness .

s- some roasted coffee malts , a little peat ?  deep mahogany in colour , crystal clear when held up to the light . the head poured thick & white then retreated to a light surface covering , still maintaining the lace on the glass .  the silky smooth mouthfeel was fantastic and carbonation was spot on .

smell : malt scent with some clear citrus and spice also . taste : malty taste with a slight hop bite .  a= pours a beautiful dark brown almost black color with a great two finger perfectly toasty looking head on it that holds awesome retention and wonderful lacing on the glass .  mouthfeel : amazing . creamy and smooth , thick .

though , if i had to guess , i would not have picked this out to be a saison . smells of bready malts , with some 'sharp ' somewhat earthy notes , - hard to describe .  ) aug. 15 2008 @ hop cat ba / brewery grand opening event , served in tulip glass . opaque black , creamy tan head , beautiful bubble suspension after pour , wow ! looks thick smells of roasty heavy malts , dark fruit , smooth and creamy , mmm taste is of thick heavy bitter chocolate , hot alcohol , rich and smooth , compared to keg this is way mellowed , not as harsh and easier to drink , amazing ! , raisins , chocolate , slight coffee , earthy peat , mm mouthfeel is oily slick , smooth , creamy , viscous , a sipper for sure - delicious !  a - opaque for sure ; not quite black , but very dark brown ; 1/2 '' tan/light brown , creamy head that diminishes to a thin layer pretty quickly ; lacing here and there , around the glass s - very nice aroma going on here ; notes of roasty malts , dark chocolate , hints of milky sweetness , and nice qualities of gingerbread too t - dark chocolate , vanilla , cinnamon , and ginger come first ; milky sweetness lasts from start to finish that is reminiscent of espresso ; slight bitter finish with roasted coffee beans and ginger as well m - medium to full bodied ; slight dry finish ; some carbonation that feels nice on the tongue ; can feel some warmth from the 9.2 % abv ; texture is very milky , creamy , velvety smooth o - i just ca n't get over how exceptionally smooth this beer really is .

this pils pours a very pale golden color with white head . nose is clean with some herbal hops in there . palate offers a nice dose of flavor though with herbal hops that bitter it up nicely , balanced with a gentle malt sweetness .  a : jet black with a nice dark mocha head that sits just barely above the beer . perfect for the style s : has a very nice mellow scotch smell that is not too harsh along side a slight sweetness of vanilla and honey .  m - they got the `` rick creamy '' part right in the description . the beer has moderate carbonation and has a nice creamy feel to it . it 's incredibly creamy and smooth and fits the style well .

i do agree the the smell is light but i get hops and very faint citrus .  the appearance is red brick with a light tan head and supreme lacing .  m - the mouthfeel is fantastic . creamy , smooth and light with a perfect amount of carbonation .

appearance this had a nice , dark , cloudy orange body with a decent head that laced a bit on my glass . smell this one is wrapped kind of tight , but the rind hops came out after a while and a touch of sweetness . yep , thats an ipa .  a : black it is ! with a thick brown head .  m : really a standout porter . carbonation is perfectly dialed in and gives a very subtle tingle on the tongue .

s : smell was a little lacking , but did smell quite refreshing , quite fir for spring !  appearance- beer pours clear and golden with a half finger of creamy white head with ample lacing on the sides of the glass . carbonation rises from the bottom of the glass as if this were a pilsner . very nice on looks at least .  m : great , chewy and resiny , full-bodied and robust , with a smooth finish , compared to the rest of the sip , just what i 'm looking for in a double ipa .

yummy ... pours a heady white-over-bronze trophy , some modest lacing which arches around delightfully un-predictable shapes ... i think i see a war-elephent trumpeting hannibal 's decent from the alps ... smell was somewhat subdued , i did n't have any good glassware handy , i used a big wine glass . smell was suggestive of good things to come , but nothing terribly fancy . this is where the fun really starts .  huge bubbly head .  the mouthfeel on this ale was great , and i think the mouthfeel of just about any beer is enhanced by cask conditioning . it had a nice thick feel on the tongue .

smell : boozey , toasty malts . uh oh.. `` dirty nickels '' .. but not that much.. lets hope we dont taste them .  for me , the appearance of a well poured guinness is stellar . the deep rich near-black mahogany tint of it , while the flow of bubbles seems to defy physics is near magical . always great poured over a bent spoon atop bass pale ale or harp lager as well !  mouthfeel : full bodied , chewy , carbonation is spot on .

smell : malt and flowers , some pine . not getting the citrusy blast that i like from an ipa , but otherwise pleasant enough . overall : very good ipa for those who prefer balance over hop bombs .  dark brown with hints of red , and a solid beige head .  it has a wonderfully creamy mouthfeel that makes each sip a pleasure .

i think if i were to drink this out of a regular pint the aroma would have come off better . t : again chocolate and coffee .  a beautiful dense white head lasts for a while and laces all the way down the glass . the color is a unique peachy-orange that is slightly opaque , and catches the light wonderfully .  the texture is likewise decadent , being somehow both silky and creamy .

the aroma is quite faint , i pick up some buttery caramel malt .  on tap at iron hill north wales , pa . served in a pint glass ... a - jet black with a 1 finger mocha head brought out to me . the head was unbelievably thick with amazing lacing that coated the entire glass .  fairly light in body for such a big beer , drinkability is good . the mouthfeel was amazing thanks to the silky , rocky head which remained throughout the entire glass .

real nice looking here . very dirty and manure like smelling . this is kind of unexpected . overall nose seems slightly off putting , but the taste more than makes up for it .  a : deep copper with a light tan head , excellent retention & lacing .  bordering on chewy as you work toward swallowing . carbonation was excellent on tap , just enough to contribute to a dry and clean finish despite the initial sweetness of the beer .

s : the weakest aspect of this beer for me . general maltiness is all i get . t : the key here is balance ; a supremely well-crafted beer .  lovely auburn red color blows me away .  huge bodied and full ( again , suggesting iipa classification ) . this is a beauty on cask .

s : nice sweet smell , but not too complex .  a : poured with a large , white fluffy head that was very long lasting ... never got below 1-2 fingers size . body is a beautiful , dark orange color , with excellent clarity .  m : so good i ca n't get enough . nice thickness with light carbonation and a good oily texture make this a delightful treat for my mouth .

a sweet malt . earthy hops , i sense not from dry hopping , but more likely late hops additions . i i had it served from a 12 oz bottle a bit too cold , which undoubtedly muted the aromas and flavors , tending them toward the bitter .  a : a stunning deep brown near black with cranberry highlights . a inch of toasted head comes after a medium pour . the head slowly fades to an impressive 1/3 inch . lacing on a dark beer ?  has that totally coating feel like a warm thick cask draught , just almost oily in its feel and velvety ( aside from the alcohol ) . really like this about this beer .

not much of an aroma , a slight nutty sweet smell . great sweet nutty , caramel , hint of toffee flavor .  its dark amber color and white head give way to perfect lacing as i drink down this wonderful libation .  perfect mouthfeel for a beer of this kind with controlled carbonation and appropriate body .

the aroma suggests yeasty caramel cream and maybe some grassy hop but overall a pretty neutral effect , with some rubbing alcohol , nothing too alluring but it 's okay . the tongue detects lots of stuff ( unlike the weak aroma ) including earthy pine and dr. pepper medicinal sweetness .  pours a thick , dense black with not so much as brown on the edges and a deep , thick tan head that rises above the lip of my snifter . this is as good of looking a stout as you will ever see . the head slowly recedes into a nice cream capping the beer leaving some nice lacing .  first sip is velvety smooth textured average body with minimal carbonation .

the aroma is pretty muffled by the head .  on a fairly gentle pour into a pint glass this pours with a huge ( 2/3 of the glass ) of white billowy slightly tan head .  and even so , it is still incredibly smooth , and the alcohol flavor can not be detected . the body is huge . one of the thickest beers i 've had the pleasure of eating . very good stuff .

first it poured a very clear medium amber , just beautiful and it 's clarity reminded me of many cask beers i have enjoyed in england . aroma was a bit of a surprise , i was expecting , or hoping maybe , for the citrusy hop character of bear republic racer 5 or el toro 's agressive interpretation . i found it very restrained and almost tea like .  a careful pour produces a robust , sandy colored , three-finger head with excellent retention and lacing .  m - this is one of my favorite parts so far about this brew . moderate amounts of carbonation that whirls around your tounge and warms it in the process .

smell- notes of citrus and rice , what one would expect .  amazing lacing & head retention , really pretty to look at s : hints of choclate & some roasted malt as it warms t : rich choclate up front , then a little grainyness & some bitter choclate .  m : medium viscosity , very smooth and creamy on the palate , with low carbonation .

the beer tastes like a dark , think stout , except that it is very carbonated in comparison . so the beer is very smooth , but with a prickle that reminds me of a hard cider . a friend of mine has an inexpensive , yet tasty scotch that she says is her `` every day '' scotch .  you get the beautiful nitrogen show and then it settles with a dark brown , almost black , body with a nice light tan head .  mouthfeel is full bodied and smooth that feels pretty creamy on the tongue .

aroma of mild citrus . it was hard to smell . had to stick my nose right down over the glass .  the appearance was amazing ! starts out pale in color and gradually becomes oranger in a way that i have never seen in a beer .  m/d - the mouthfeel and drinkability are exceptional . this is a simple brown ale that i could knock back one after the other .

lacing consists of large swaths of bubbles clinging to the glass , which dry out over time . smells fairly bright for a porter . roasted dark malts are at an appreciable minimum . ah , the nose does n't do the taste justice .  pours a very inky black with a dark brown creamy head . very oily and sudsy , looks great .  m - thick , very smooth and very viscous with little carbonation .

it has a nice colour and can easily be consumed on mass while watching either the maple leafs of the blue jays . i find that creemore does not have the best aroma and infact it greatly detracts from the flavour .  enjoyed in a pint glass a : moderate pour yields 1 finger of thick dark brown head that sticks around .  mouthfeel . amazing , thick rich and seems sweet but comes together .
