smell is faint , like cupcakes baking in the oven as you approach the house ( no , that does n't actually happen in my household ) . not as hoppy as i expected , but the hops are delicious and balance the beer nicely . but it 's still a terrific beer .  12oz bottle poured into a pint glass pours a copper-straw with obvious carbonation bubbles rising to the surface . any head quickly fades to nothing .  thick creamy mouthfeel and mild carbonation . smooth silky mouthfeel is lucious .

the smell is quite pleasant , kind of like a forest with a lot of wet leaves on the ground .  first off , i thought this beer was very delicious ... and i will certainly buy another ! i do n't know if i poured mine incorrectly , but it was very cloudy ... which i thought oktoberfests are supposed to be clear ( i 'm thinking about spaten , sam adams , and the like ) . in fact , i loved it !  full effervescent body , huge amounts of carbonation . an unusual beer that 's quite good .

muddled malts are rather roasted and somewhat sweet . some coffee , perhaps . not the best . t : this more than makes up for the subpar flavour . the flavour is full of smoked chocolate , soft roasted malts , and nutty notes . d : quite drinkable , warming , filling , and satisfying . i 'm impressed .  appearance is dark yellow with a few big bubbles which hung on the glass .  thick rich and creamy mouthfeel . for such a rich and big beer it is remarkably smooth .

smell is all malt and little hops ... i do n't detect a hint of citrus or hops smell at all .  i poured this beer from the bottle to a tumbler at 45 degrees . color was amber okay head that decayed pretty fast .  perfectly carbonated , with a thick chewy body and a strong alcohol burn .

s - not much going on smell wise , reserved , yet some hints of dark roast , fresh mulled grains .  the beer poured a hazy burnished amber with next to nothing of a head .  m - fairly heavy body and solid flavors with moderate carbonation . the flavors are spot , the mouthfeel is amazing and its very drinkable .

smell - decent malty pale ale aroma .  possibly the worse beer i have ever had..sickeningly sweet..i let it sit for a week in my fridge and it still bubbled over with head . tastes like sugar and the 1st beer i 've ever simply poured down the drain..is there a quality control problem here or is this standard for the beer ?  very palatable and no alcohol taste at all m - silky smooth , great carbonation .

appearance - very rich amber/red colors with a nice 1/2 '' - 3/4 '' head smell - slightly hoppy but not a very strong smell taste - sweet and smooth with no bitterness mouthfell - very smooth and pleasant . drinkability - this stuff is very easy to guzzle . everyone sitting with me at my table tried this and everyone ( non-beer drinkers included ) was very impressed .  aside from the sediment that slowly floated like stars on a cool new hampshire evening the overall appearance was pretty average , striking shiny copper .  body is simply luxurious - rich , creamy , and damn near perfect .

it smells nothing special really , typically acoholic smell really , a bit like whiskey .  got a nice 1 finger head on the pour but the coloring of the body is fairly weak . very light orange almost the shade of a pilsner which is not a good look for an ipa . smell is very juicy sweet pineapple with the expected belgian yeast twang of clove and banana .  mouthfeel is very soft and full bodied with light carbonation .

the smell was really subtle for me and i could n't detect anything more than a slight sweetness like burnt caramel .  it poured an amazingly still very dark , almost obsidian brown . there is no head , just occasional bubbles surfacing .  s : caramel , apple , sweet roasted malt t : tastes of caramel , some sour fruit like apple , yeast and hops bitterness/spice , some booze m : beautifully creamy and thick , but has a sharpness from the medium carbonation and booze o : drinkable for a bottle at least , this is an awesome beer .

the smell does nothing for the beer , it is very light , made me not expect much from this beer .  from a growler into a frosty mason-jar mug at purv 's beer and more in peckville , pa lighter in appearance than i had expected . smell was of straight cocoa powder and a little bit of spice from the chili pepper mouthfeel was very nice considering the light color .  m : one of the most enjoyable mouthfeels i 've ever had in a beer ; medium-bodied and moderately carbonated , immensely smooth and surprisingly creamy . d : i thought that the taste here was good , not great ... but the amazing mouthfeel and complex flavor keep drawing me back in , and at much faster rate than that of many beers whose tastes i prefer .

s : ho-hum aroma , even as it nears room temperature . ends flowery and just a little soapy . ) compared to the bracingly hoppy ipas 'round these parts , but i do n't mind .  hazy light amber with a thin , off-white head that fades , becoming patchy . little bit of lacing .  the mouthfeel is , in a word , glorious . smooth on the tip of the tongue , then seeming to evaporate off your tongue leaving a crisp , somewhat spicy finish .

a- beautiful rich amber with a dense creamy head . s- a little faint , but my allergies are clogging my nose a bit so , it 's probably better than i can tell . some floral , some hoppy spiciness . first i get the fresh pine and resin notes , very bright and spicy , with floral overtones throughout . i do n't like bitterness and its the only fault i have with this beer , but since it is a tribute to hops its really not a fault at all .  pours a copper color with what starts out as a nice creamy head but almost instantly recedes into a thin film . minimal lacing left behind .  m : carbonation is explosive ( like the cork escapade ) . tickles the mouth with just the right amount of chewiness .

a deep brown color gives the initial stout impression but a light citrusy aroma is present leading one to believe it 's and ipa .  pours a clear golden with a decent amount of slow rising carbonation , with a thin white head with a bit short retention , but is not too inspiring .  m : full-bodied and lightly carbonated with a soft and creamy texture . alcohol noticable in a nice warming effect .

smell of alcohol and malts . color was bodacious . mouthfeel was like heavenly night blooming jasmine with a hint of mirliitons and cypress buds .  golden orange body , brilliant in the light . compact , slightly khaki head bubbles out to a collection of foam on the sides of the glass . minimal lacing .  finshes warming , hoppy & bready , very balanced approach mf : chewy with low carbonation & great balance dangerously drinkable , this would put you on your butt after a couple of pints but a really nice dipa

nice straw gold , big rolicking white head . nothing special . grainy at first , gives way pretty quickly to caramel . finish could use some work , it just sort of ... ends . needs some hopping to bulk up the backend . very drinkable , nice for a hot summer day .  this -bal barleywine pours with almost zero head .  just take a sip and get lost in the nearly overpowering flavor explosion and the creamy tingly mouthfeel of this wondrous scottish ale .

the aromas are relatively straight forward with caramelized sugars and a raisin smell in the background .  this brew arrived at my table essentially headless . lacing was very sparse .  a full bodied beer that is creamy smooth and goes down really easy .

aroma is soft , but of coarse hops , but for the most part rather clean . medium in body , and smooth .  a refreshing light-bodied ale that goes down easy a- very clear amber-yellow with thin , big-bubbled head s- smells a bit like honey along with a bottle/metal hint .  appearance : cloudy burnt orange/brown - nice head retention smell : cinnamon , nutmeg , pumpkin spice taste : hops , cinnamon , coriander , nutmeg - similar to an american wild ale - very tannic mouthfeel : my favorite part very tannic , smooth - the rye dries the palate out so you 're ready for another sip or another bite of food .

smell : the alcohol is very evident , a sweet syrupy smell and raisins are the only other aromas i pick out . taste : the flavor profile is dominated by raisins and syrup , with warming alcohol in the finish . overall : one dimensional , and cloyingly sweet .  a : a hazy orange color . me thinks this is bottle conditioned given all the haze.. nice white head , that dissipates into a white ring .  m - absolutely creamy and delectable ! the amazing , tiny bubbled froth envelopes and contains any alcohol sharpness that would otherwise make this 8.0 % beer a bit fiery in the swallow . superb . d - the mouthfeel makes this otherwise straight-up scotch ale an incredibly drinkable beverage . but be careful ! at 8 % , this beer is like getting a two-for-one special in each pint !

smell : yeasty . maybe some very mellow goldings or fuggles .  first observations : whoa , what a smell ! the appearance is dark , of course ... .well more of a dark red . not much head or retention , but i did n't expect much .  mouthfeel is the best part of the beer .

smell is fairly muted , some lemon , some belgian yeast . wish the smell was more pronounced .  not too much retention of the white head , but did pour a nice light amber color that was very clear . not much lacing to be seen .  smooth and creamy mouthfeel makes the small tickling carbonation and otherwise heavier body very palatable . i do n't know if so much milk is my thing , but i 'm glad i tried it .

smell : it 's kind of a let-down smell wise actually . some slightly sour hops and some nutty malts . does n't really smell that great to be honest .  on to the beer : there was no head on this beer when i received it in my tulip . the color is chocolate brown wih hues of caramel orange . very lightly carbonated , and no , this was n't from the infamous bottles of the 2008 vintage , but a keg ( sorry , do n't know what vintage ) .  mouthfeel : low carbonation leads to thirsty gulps .

a - clear , ruby red , aggressive poor produces no lacing s - not a lot going on here , maybe some figs or plums and vanilla or caramel t - wonderfully subdued representation of the same aromas in the nose m - very smooth and creamy with just enough carbonation for a clean finish d - impressive for 10 % .  pours a pale copper color with an off white head from a brown twist off bottle .  m- very , very thick and chewy . also quite heavy .

s : light on any nose , what i could smell was a bit malty , but otherwise the entire scent was nearly non-existent . t : fantastic ! powerful , full malt with slight yet perfectly blended hops . i was a bit turned off by the smell , but as soon as i had a swig , i was totally impressed .  a - poured a caramely copper-colored body with modest carbonation and very little head that quickly disappeared and left no lacing .  mouth-feel was velvety smooth and creamy .

this is one of my favorites , this is the alt which is available year around at the brewery on tap . the bottle pales in comparison to the tap version . love to spend a rainy afternoon enjoying an alt and the good company at the brewery . when at the berwery , i hope you get to meet nick , one of the last great bartenders - great way to spent a portland afternoon .  it pretty much looks like muddy pond water , but this look in a beer is actually sort of exciting , because it signals me that i am in for an interesting experience .  great bubbly mouthfeel , no aftertaste at all .

s : not a real pungent smell ... .a little dank . not bad but nothing special . t : nice well balanced hop beer .  a - pours very dark brown in color with some light that is able to make it through around the edges revealing some ruby highlights . the tan head was quite minimal showing very little retention and leaving very little lace .  m/d : full bodied , very smooth , velvet like .

s - plenty of malt , not much else .  slight amounts of sediment adds to the mild haziness . no lacing , and just about no head , but there is a slight cloud of head floating around . m- full and very smooth .  mouthfeel : perfection . the bead is neither too large nor too small .

maybe it 's just me , but i did n't get much aroma from this . just a hint of toasted grain .  a : pitch black with a one-finger head . poor head retention and no lacing . it looks like others have had a better looking pour ... perhaps i have this beer a little too much tlc .  they served it properly too - the temperature was perfect ( not co cold ) . pretty close to perfect .

dales ' has a mildly hoppy bite and leaves little aftertaste - due to storage , i think . all-in-all , an exceptional quaff , though i do prefer oskar blues scotch ale `` old chubb .  ( a ) - pours a very thick cloudy caramel color .  caramel , mocha , strong booze , brown sugar , raisins , figs , chocalate t-malt , mocha , booze , brown sugar , caramel , raisins figs , chocalate m-spicy , creamy , thick , barely carbonated d- pretty thick & filling .

smells of faint hop aromas and not much else . clean , crisp and refreshing .  appearance : deep dark brown , no head retention smell : lemon , toasty nutty malts taste : balanced sour ale , plenty of sweetness to go with the sour aspect of the beer .  m - big bodied , thick , and viscous as hell . middling carbonation fades to a really dry and herbal finish like green tea . wicks all moisture from my mouth !

aroma of burnt toffee - more like a brown ale to me . very tasty , hop flavor mixes well with the roasty , chewy grains . no yeast trub in this bottle .  ommegang adoration special winter ale belgian strong dark ale bottle dated 7/18/11 and poured into a tulip on 1/5/12 a . pours a murky deep reddish brown with a 1 inch off white head .  big , viscous mouthfeel does great things for this beer , transmitting a pretty large package ( 10 % , significant ibu count ) into an easy-to-sip package .

s : musky and earth aromas . burnt cherry and very malty . farly nondescript as far as i am concerned . i did not know what to expect , but this is an exceptional beer . though , to fully appreciate this , i need to be more familiar with the style .  received one fat finger of head that quickly faded . brownish copper colored body was clear .  mouthfeel is where this one shines , smooth as can be and perfectly carbonated , a light yet creamy quality .

the aroma does n't seem so bad ; perhaps even pleasant - prairie grass , damp pollen , clean grains and hints of mild spice . there 's a lemon grass element as well , but i 'm concerned the lemon smells too ... pungent . yuck .  pours a two finger white head that fades slowly leaving traces of lace . cloudy almost pale amber color .  nice touch of bitterness lingers as i contemplate the rich , full mouth feel . nice beer , much more approachable than the expedition .

s : chocolate malt , cocoa , coffee grounds and a hint of plastic that fades out after a few minutes of sitting out .  pours deep auburn with large bubbles in the tan head and leaves no ring or lacing inside the pint glass .  mouthfeel is astonishingly smooth and creamy for such a rich , complex ale .

this widely available ale saved me from the tyranny of the irish dry stouts when i toured ireland a few years ago . it smells slightly of grainy malt , and not much else .  a- cloudy golden tan topped with an off white head . the head fades quickly to a ring and leaves a little spotty lace on the glass .  amazing mouthfeel . viscous , rich and creamy without being syrupy .

s : malty , bready , yeasty and a bit hoppy . t : caramel sweet malt with toffee flavors , great malt/hop balance .  poured chilled in flared glass a : thin head ; good carbonation ; dark cola color ; not much lacing s : nutmeg , pumpkin , caramel ; inviting t : very satisfying ; alcohol and spices ( nutmeg , allspice ) prominent ; hops are very strong , providing complexity some reviewers complain about the abundant hops , but i find that an asset in a pumpkin beer ( a style i tend not to prefer ) .  mouthfeel- soft , silky smooth texture . full bodied and rich . perfect .

the smell is not all that appealing . it is way earthy and at first it reminded me of an ashtray . the mouthfeel is excellent very `` wet '' and good finish . overall , a very nice beer .  for pilsner drinkers , this beer has the smoothness and malt flavor one would expect , although oftentimes that leaves a beer without a distinct taste . very drinkable and when finished , would definitely look for another scrimshaw .  really big round full mouthfeel .

the nose had some malt , and a light note of candy .  here 's my first dipa from iowa ... a - pours a reddish brown / dark amber without much of a head on it s - smells dank and boozy with lots of earthy , oniony hops with citrus undertones .  m : full body , and shockingly creamy . this brew is extremely smooth of the mouth .
nose is very tame and toasty .  appearance : it poured a translucent amber color with a small white head with poor retention and no lace .  very full and creamy mouth . damn tasty .
aroma seems a little incomplete , with yeast smells and a touch of leather .  a : hazy amber , nice small white foamy head .  it seemed to just coat my whole mouth on its way down .

poured into a some big ass glass ... appearance-amber body , very dark pale ale . some skunk , not sure what the date is on this bottle ... taste-tart granny smith apple along with some sweet caramel malts .  really does look like coffee when poured from bottle to glass . black brew with a dark mud brown head . lack of lingering head makes tcois look like motor oil .  this beer is silky smooth with very well behaved carbonation - you 'll have no trouble taking big gulps of this brew !

smells ok ... ca n't exactly put my finger on what is wrong ... but it may have something to do with the `` party pig '' it came from .  after gearing myself up , i cracked my 60 minute ipa with great expectations . this beer has a slight hint of a head that disappears immediately and leaves a lousy lacing .  ( m ) mouthfeel is perfect for this beer .

slight malty nose . starts mellow with some sweetness , finish is more malt than hop with no aftertaste .  1999 vintage , sampled nov , 2003 - no head whatsoever . solid black in color with slight garnet highlights around the edges .  t : the taste was about average for a stout , almost identical in flavor to guinness m : amazing mouthfeel , so creamy and so smooth .

the smell was fruity , sweet and slightly hoppy .  the head is a light brown and the body is a dark brown.the head is very froffy.some lacing on the glass . i would like to try this on tap.this a very lively brown ale and it has feeling to it.not watery one bit and the carbonation is pleasant.another great ale from dfh .  light in body with absolutely wonderful carbonation , this is airy , creamy and the combination of sourness and spiciness on the finish is unique .

aroma : slight grainy aroma . i was surprised i did n't pick up on those traits in the aroma . grapefruit notes . i really liked the way this beer came together .  appearance almost resembles a cola . not as dark as other porters . little to no lacing .  mouthfeel was full and rich . this is a very good beer , and quite a unique one .

aroma of coffee though initially strong fades to subtle . the taste is superior to the smell . good mouthfeel with pleasant carbonation .  it pours a nice light amber , maybe more of a copper in color . a tad disappointing with a slight head the did fade a bit , there is some slight lacing on the sides of my glass .  had an appropriate lower level of carbonation that many ris can not compete against . rich and thick on the palate . very warming .

s : the combination of hops and funk is a little weird . nothing about the smell is jumping out and telling me that i want to drink the beer , but it 's not off-putting , really . it 's quite sharp , and big kind of like a double ipa . it 'd be nice to slip in a saison dupont or hennepin between servings .  poured into the typical ale house 20oz nonic pint glass . '' appearance : the beer pours a deep amber red color with a thin off-white head that does not last . i do n't think i have ever had a beer poured at the ale house that did have a nice head though .  the mouthfeel is excellent .

original rating date : august 30 , 2008 pours an enticing dark gold , smells of a bit of hops but not as much as i expected , relatively weak on the nose which surprises me as most iipas i 've tried have a great nose . looking down the ratings already here , it seems like i 'm the only one who will score this weak on aroma- maybe my nose is too stuffed ? i want to give this a higher rating but the nose just was n't there for me . either way , excellent iipa , a far better effort than lagunitas ' regular ipa .  appearance : dark brown with a tan , creamy lace . there was a hell of a lot of sediment in the bottle .  perfect in this sense .

the day after i review the bottle : i walk into my local and it 's on a cask hand pull , what a lovely surprise . the smell was , like the bottled one , it 's weakest part and although there were hop and malt esters they did n't excite or bother the nose at all . the last paragraph is almost the same as my bottle review : really liked the mouthfeel and taste , good blend of ingredients to produce a fine beer .  poured into pint glass a : dark , opaque looking . very little tan head that quickly dissipated . i am new to drinking porters so i 'm not sure if a frothy head is to be expected .  the mouth feel on this one is perfect . the head retention is outstanding and just adds to that smooth , creamy , malty , citrus finish .

the malt smells wonderful but no hop aroma .  a - reddish brown brew with a big head and a little bit of scattered lacing .  smooth and thick ( of medium thickness ) , with small abrasive bubbles ( in the best possible way ) . wish i had let it chill a little longer to see a greater range of flavors as it warmed , but still a nice experience .

it does n't really have any overpowering aromas . both the hops and malt are pretty subtle . it 's very drinkable , especially for a pale .  pours a light golden color with a thick bubbly off white head .  mouthfeel - very smooth with a rich body and muted carbonation .

smell : caramel and mild bitterness are detectable .  pours a clear , relatively pale brownish red . half finger light tan head formed on the pour then quickly dissipated . quite lightly and finely carbonated . essentially no lacings .  the mouthfeel is what really sets this apart . having had very few english cask ales , i do n't know if this is gold standard , but it is the best mouthfeel i 've had on this style beer .

very easy drinking ale with nice dark copper color and good lacing . makes a good session ale or good beer to introduce to non craft beer drinkers who will occasionally drink guiness stout .  pours a murky brown-fuschia with an odd colored pink/brown head . not exactly a looker .  my favorite thing about this obviously the sweet rich malt character which adds to a very nice body for a beer of this alcohol content .
the aroma is a pretty subtle combination of lemony and herbal notes .  poured a deep orange color with good carbonation but no head to speak of .  mouthfeel very full and smooth .

the aroma is pleasant but muted , with a nondescript sweet and somewhat tart character .  a - poured out a clear , dark burgundy color with a very small , thin head of off-white foam .  it 's as smooth as silk - perfectly suited as a dinner and desert sipper and easily the best porter i 've had the pleasure of tasting .

smell is faint . i get some hop and yeasty malt , but not a really forward nose .  a - pours a crystal clear ruby brown with a thin layer of head which quickly dissipates leaving no lacing . very little visible carbonation .  perhaps there is similar inconsistency here , and i will be wowed by the bottles i brought home sometime in the future ... mouthfeel is by far the best characteristic , supple , creamy and light .

hobgoblin is a very easy going down brown ale that is a perfect session beer .  poured golden with a 1/2 '' white head . minimal head retention & lacing s : perfumy hops & straw t : straw , floral hops & akiss of malt up front .  appearance : amber , clear carbonated , medium head smell : alcohol , grapefruit , and citrus taste : alcohol , grapefruit , malts , hops , and slight caramel mouthfeel : smooth , slightly hard finish , can feel the carbonation ... it is amazing how smooth and unbitter this beer is for a beer with its abv drinkability : i will have this again , but may be one of the few that prefer the 60 minute ipa .

the beer 's scent was almost entirely hops for me . it seemed to be a one dimensional flavor profile to the scent . i did n't get very much matlyness in the smell . the flavor was really where this beer started to pick up .  this one pours very clear and almost `` light '' looking for an ipa , it 's a rather light amber with a puny head .  m : thick and rich , with a nice amount of fine , late-developing carbonation . perfect for such a big beer .

small white head that dissipates quickly from my tap pour at the airport taproom . lack of noticeable smell , which i find from most tap beers .  poured this 375 ml green bottle into a lindemans flute . the first pour was clear golden with many tiny bubbles clinging to the sides . the second pour was murkier .  mouthfeel is extremely smooth & this is a perfect beer to sip on on a lazy pm with no kids in sight !

the smell is average , its not bad or obtrusive , but there is very little of anything that i could smell , neutral to the most . its fairly simple , but sometimes excellence is in simplicity . very clean finish .  it 's a dark lager with a brown-orange hue and very little head that somehow fades to less head .  the malt is well back but the beer still has a nice light body . the palate is a great balance of all that and a nice honey quality in the background .

aroma is some light malt , some caramel , raisin . quite subdued though .  hope i gave you something good.. a - pours a very hazy brown with small white head that latched onto the side of the glass .  mouthfeel is perfect and this is a pretty drinkable brew .

good color - darker than i might have expected s - a little sweet .. i dont find this beer to have a pronounced smell of any kind .  a : 'midnight ' dark ( nearly black ) pour , with a slim head . good ringing lace that trails fang-like tendrils of tawny film ... but overall , eh it 's just an average stout , nothing remarkable whatsoever .  very excellent mouthfeel and drinkability .

extremely malty bready nose for a beer this hopped-up . very clean hit .  i 'll be brief on this one because this is an experience that will be very different from person to person and the bottle temp is as important as its age in evaluating this beer . if you like big beer this is the circus fat lady of big drink it slow and share it with a friend . also this is a good beer to lay down and enjoy aged . malt , malt , malt ! !  mouthfeel : on the heavy side of the medium-bodied scale and creamy smooth .

a very faint smell , hard to put a nose on it but there 's some sweetness there .  not like motor oil , more like tobacco water . it 's damn near a hop bomb . very drinkable . i get a real dry finish from porters , maybe it 's relative to the color , but that dryness coupled with the hops makes me want more & more each sip i take .  entering the mouth , i immediately take notice of the huge mouthfeel on this . this is fluffy , powdery , quaffable , and has this charming soft carbonation that is typical of great beers . palate displays a superb spicy bitterness executed in incredible balance and harmony ( this and the mouthfeel are the 2 attractions imo ) , gentle woodiness .

the aroma is average . it has a weird black malt scent that is a bit tart smelling .  appearance : this pours a hazy brown color with no head .  what i really loved was the mouthfeel . very good for a lager style beer .

smell is mostly of malt and a bit of hops not much there .  this beer looks a bit too light for an english ipa .  mouthfeel : thick and smooth in every sense of the words -- a very pleasant experience indeed !

the aroma was underwhelming but neutral grainy .  bottle a pale golden , yellowish straw color . aggressive pour yielded little head , but decent carbonation and some nice sediment .  subtly carbonated , with a medium-full body and a delightful smoothness .

a- pours chocolate milk color into black with the creamiest of tan heads . s- aroma is soft and roasted , not much going on . perfect amount of malt .  a- nice deep gold color , no head , but with med-high carbonation .  a - bright golden orange color with some chill haze present , two fingers of white frothy head that leaves thick froth-lace s - not too much rye here , just hints ... hops and bready malt t - hop bitterness up front , sweet bready malts in the back , only a hint of rye in the middle ... the malt backing is about as significant as it gets ... taste 's more like a straight up ipa than most rye beers i 've had m - hops tingle the tongue and give way to very thick , chewy malts that slide down nicely ... full-bodied and very enjoyable d - this is a reeeally well-balanced beer , i just wanted more rye flavor .

very straight up pale lager smell , it does supply some decent scents of fruit and bread . much more flavorful than expected !  a - poured out a clear , bubbly , light orange color with a small , white , fizzy head . not much in terms of lace .  this belgian pale ale has a strong cookie-like malt character and an exceptionally smooth mouthfeel .

aroma was surprisingly weak , notes of smoky roasted malt and hints of coffee .  poured from the bottle into a pint glass a - pours a dark copper with virtually no head . perhaps that explains the lackluster head ...  mouthfeel is really exceptional , which along with the smooth flavors is what i really like .

this rauchmalt is combined with modest amounts of crystal malt and two types of chocolate malt that add sweet and chocolaty notes to balance the assertive smoke qualities . hops really take a backseat in this style , so as not to interfere with the complex smoky aromatics '' -- free state this pours a very dark brown almost black . unfortunately , the aroma is weak . some very small tinges of smoke come out , but not much else .  poured into a snifter on 7/5/10 many thanks to pdxhops dark brown in color , settling black in the glass . in fact all foam disappears save a ring . no lace .  thick lushious body and moderate carbonation .

s : a little sour and yeasty , followed by fruit . pears , figs and banana . i can just see a abbey full of monks enjoying this out of chalices , and having a great time .  very nearly black in color with good clarity on the pour . the head is a nice crema color but settles almost instantly .  feels amazingly clean and fresh while keeping the flavor of charred wood and grains . smooth , creamy , full bodied , and almost a velvet nature . the carbonation is played on in the background as an overcoat . the simplicity of it overwhelms me .

the aroma was nice , but nothing special .  looks just like the dam straight .  m : the feel is excellent with fine carbonation lending a creaminess that is top-tier and a clean scrubbing finish with the right balance of crispness and aftertaste . d : an fine tripel with classic light fruit flavors mixed artfully with pepper and spice and a top-notch mouthfeel compose a very good brew .

sidenote : waitress tells me this name of this beer was chosen because a song by the same name was being played while it was brewed . aroma is toasted malt and caramel .  pours a bright clear straw-yellow color with a good inch of soft whitish head .  mouthfeel is really impressive . very gradual on the tongue and extraordinarily balanced .

s : not the best aspect of this beer -- smells a lot like balsamic vinegar without much of the underlying fruit coming through . t : quite tart with a bit of barnyard horse blanket .  dark brown color , slightly opaque , a 2/3-finger head that hangs around for a decent while before disappearing ; the drink does n't leave too much lacing behind .  again this is a beer with a very good character but i still feel it does n't perfectly balance m- incredible mouthfeel .

smell is minimal ( beer could have been too cold at first ) taste is nice and malty that grows as it gets a bit warmer .  my old foghorn came in a 7 oz bottle warning me about the high strength of the beer . the beer was not highly carbonated either . the color was a light brownish-amber , and was noticably cloudy as well .  not the stunner i was hoping for m- beautiful mouth feel . i sure hope this is not the `` great sculpin '' i 've been waiting for for that past few years .

s - malt aroma accented by hops .  produces a weak brown head with poor retention and no lacing .  the mouth-feel was what was remarkable to me , very thick and creamy , i would liken it to a stout milkshake , really satisfying and enjoyable to drink .

s : not a big smell . yeasty . overall : the smell does n't set you up propery for how the taste hits you in the mouth .  presentation : on tap . appearance : hazy amberish brown .  perfect carbonation .

regeneration very good . hoppy front end , chocolate notes , roasted malts and a long finish , nicely balanced , oatmeal , any spices were subdued .  pours out a deep clear . almost amber , very llittle head , a bit of lacing .  the mouthfeel is exceptionally smooth and creamy , terrific . thanks bif for the sample .

aroma is the only thing that falls a bit short here as the hops are in the back somewhere . the aroma does have a touch of burnt caramels which is coming through from the rye . nice job on this one , just missing a little on the aroma end for what i was expecting .  a straw-colored pilsner that pours with an initial frothiness that falls quickly leaving a little bit of lace .  outstanding mouthfeel ! very drinkable .

almost black in color , charcoal/black licorice , hardly affected by light when held up . s- faint sweetness , molasses maybe . hard to fully describe the scent other than it definitely had some sweet tones to it .  bottle poured into pint glass appearance : nothing to write home about . light lacing , amber-gold in color .  mouthfeel is big full and smooth very rich and easy drinking with a really satisfing warming in the gut .

lightest and sweetest helles yet -- perhaps even paler than a us macro . i like jason 's grape skin description . sidenote : bit of a clinical , soapy scent in the glass .  golden amber color , thin white head that dissipates very quickly . extremely drinkable , with a lot of flavor while it is in your mouth but no aftertaste , so it begs for the next sip .  taste- for a double ipa , this beer is not on a mission to wreck the palate ... with so much flavor i 'm surprised that the malts weigh in so heavily . solid . it 's sudsy ( the name of my beloved late parakeet ) and sublime . drinkability- one real attribute about this bruiser of a beer is that the abv ( 10 % ) is completely hidden ... it 's nowhere in any of the above categories . this is more like a nectar , thick and juicy , garnering respect for each sip .

had an imperial pint at mac 's taproom , slighshot is a clear pale copper with a small off-white head that leaves moderate lace . smell is very muted , especially when first served a bit to cold , sweet soft cereals and grassy hops .  pours a deep amber from the bottle , off-white head that dissipates quickly leaving thin lacing .  super creamy mouthfeel w/o any overcarbed bite .

slight fruity aroma but nothing stands out here .  there was pretty much no head , but a bit of lacing around the sides .  loved the residual stickiness . d- it 's remarkable how fff can make such big beers and hide the alcohol so well .

tannish head sits heavy at first , fades and laces . rusty malt scent . deep and dark .  6 % abv 45 ibu a : straw-red in color with a good amount of haze . there is a decent off-white head that floats atop this brew .  delicious . and i think what makes it delicious is not entirely a taste thing , but a feel thing . so smooth and creamy and round without any heaviness or stickiness . and it 's an appropriate textural delivery for the huge fruits here ( again , fig , plum and raisin dominant ) ; smoky cherry continues to remind of pipe tobacco ; a more general/generic smoke flavor nicely sneaks in with warming ; and there 's a milky chocolate essence entering into the flavor that i did n't detect in the smell .

lots of yeast sediment in the bottle . smell - not much just a little bit of citrusy hops , candy , a bit of alcohol , and a bit of sweet caramel malt . smells of cascade hops . taste - starts out with a sweet caramel malt taste , followed by some grassy and earthy hops , a bit of citrus twang mostly as graperfuit and then the bitterness .  there was absolutely no head or carbonation and even a vigorous pour resulted only in some air bubbles on top .  full of body and creamy goodness .

s - has an aroma of apple cider mixed with a heavy dose of cloves and a very mild hint of pumpkin . also some mild banana-like esters . enough said .  750 ml bottle , great label , opens with a champagne like pop , a : pours a deep red umber to brown with an initial three finger head which recedes quickly to a smooth cap of foam , no lace is a surprise . arguably the most authentic belgianesque mouthfeel i 've had in an american made , belgian style beer , reminds me a ton of achel brune in this respect . very impressive .  mouthfeel : medium-bodied with a dry , perfectly carbonated finish . perfect for the style .
aroma - a light roasty grain and smoked peat . pleasant but fragile levels .  appearance = pretty average looking clear , light golden straw-amber . not much head at all .  creamy but thin body .

s- the smell was very subtle . there was some sweet maltiness and some mild floral characteristics noted .  sweet f.a head , leaves a spiderweb of lace atop a very dark body , little in the way of highlights when held up to the light . there are lots of bubbles breaking the surface though which is odd for a porter .  mouthfeel is wow smooth , and drinkability is amazingly good .

certainly has that belgain yeatiness to it as well as the smell of good old alcohol .  a : copper-bronze , off-white head , no retention or lace .  body is n't the first thing you notice , but once the distraction of the sour wears off , you realize this brew is very smooth , neither tacky nor sticky , nor drying . carbonation can be swirled up , and compliments the feel of the sour in your cheeks quite well . all in all , a crazy departure from the normal dfh offerings and dang fine weissen .

think of a nice malt being toasted . keep toasting it until it is black and almost burnt or charcoal and make guinness . when you make this beer do everything exactly the same just change how much you toast the malt . to me i like the dark toast flavor and color of kilkenny the best . the taps for kilkenny say it is brewed by guinness .  the beer pours a dark brown color with a frothy beige head foaming up and fading quickly to an edge layer .  the mouthfeel is great , for the bittersweetness from the roasted malts provide the ideal amount of oomph to an otherwise creamy body .

i smell chocolate and coffee and malt and even some hops . very nice and somewhat unique representation of the style .  dull orange straw color with a little haze hanging around , the head starts off big but then falls to a thin layer of lace .  in addition , there are hop oils , caramel , some sweetness and perhaps molasses along with a medium body that is oh so smooth and coats the mouth well . delicious and well balanced .

s - caramel and a slight coffee aroma . t - there 's a chocolate flavor accompanied by a caramel taste .  a : cloudy yellow/orange color with some suspended solids . broken , thin lacing ; none near the end .  excellent for it 's style .

s : herbaceous and slightly spicy , with some suggestion of lime citrus and fresh berry fruit . overall intensity of the smell is weak , giving an impression of vacancy . t : begins off-dry , with pithy grapefruit peel and crackery pilsner malt .  pours a clear yet deep amber with a fast two finger , receding head . very little bubbling and no lacing , but good color though .  very full body that stretches the cheeks . just such chewy hops .

( s ) - a dry , yet floral-like citrus . a damp wood-like pine . ( t ) - a fresh & crisp floral citrus of lemon , pineapple , grapefruit , and lime . has everything you would expect from the style .  pours cloudy pale yellow with minimal white head .  a nice chewy , creamy malt backbone makes each sip a pleasure .

this is the first time i 've bought leinenkugel 's on my own and i 'm very delighted in the results . smell is bland and much less present than any other aspect .  pours clear golden with a thin white head . the appearance is not much to write about .  some of the best damn mouthfeel you will ever get in a beer too .

this was by far , the worst `` beer '' i 've ever tasted . if this bottle was n't infected , and was supposed to taste like that , i 'm downright confused .  pours an orangish-amber into a pint glass with very little foam .  the mouthfeel was awesome - very creamy and full bodied .

s - i am hard pressed to find much in the nose beyond a light , pleasant flowery hop . very good beer , though i feel the appearance and aroma are weak for a bspa .  pours a really fizzy white head over a cloudy peach-colored liquid .  perfectly suited for sipping and just right for the flavor .

s - bright hops and citrus predominate , but overall not particularly strong odors .  recieved this bottle froma friend at ab in st. louis . not a test bottle , but , a production bottle . a : milky brown , tan puffy head . nice lacing .  m - amazing . low to moderate carbonation ( expected ) and full bodied .

pulled it from the cooler in a bottle at around 8pm and took a sip , whatever kind of sweet , watery whatever , but it down and played a pick up game of football for around fifteen minutes . when i returned to my beer it didn`t even taste the same , when this beer gets a chance to warm up a bit its flavor really shines through , it tasted so smooth , like a golden apple dunked in orange juice , with toher very warming herbs , a great brew to transition into autumn brews .  pours a dirty red-brown in color and only a very thin ring of a head clings to the glass . no lacing .  wow . the thick and creamy mouthfeel is perfect for the winter months and so warm .

the nose is subtle , but has a little bit of winter spice .  big malt aroma ( munich-type , sort of crystal but with a light roasty component ) with some grainy cereal notes . seems a little light colored for the style , just barely off gold , with a touch of haziness . smallish head that fades after a little while . very nice malty profile . hop bitterness is well in balance but still very subtle . clean fermentation .  m- perfect for the style , ca n't say anything more .

a hazy copper pour with a sustaining head , the beer smells sort of indistinct for the hops and malt you 'd expect .  a little head retention & no lacing s : slight earthy hops up front then a little fruittyness t : piney hops up front followed by fruittyness & a slight grainyness .  mouthfeel is creamy smooth , thick body , low carbonation .

s - heavy horse has a classic aroma of toasted malt with notes of caramel , toffee , and a pinch of nuttiness but is hindered by a dry , strong mineral finish .  i 've had plenty of these in my day , but this is the first i 've actually sat down with to review ... a - pours a slightly cloudy , orangish copper color , a little darker than alot of ipas . head grows to about 1 inch before settling down to a thin outer layer .  smooth and creamy , very soft carbonation . booze is extremely well hidden .

the aroma is composed of citrus and yeast . i detect the slight prenence of hops in the aroma . the flavor is slight on the front of the tongue , but the hops are prevelent on the back of the tongue .  exceptionally fizzy cloudy and golden appearance .  first sip reveals a smooth and slightly creamy texture , carbonation is almost non-existent as cask ale should be .

overall i enjoyed it , the smell still does n't please me but the beer in general is quite good .  beer arrived with almost no head at all . color was very dark , almost appearing black at first .  it 's just smooth and thick enough to feel perfect going down .

the smell was very faint , hints of breads and malts . great taste ; earthy , bready , and lightly hoppy .  pours murky muddy brown with large bubbled brown head .  mouthfeel : crisp , clean , and exceedingly refreshing .
s- wheat , slightly hoppy , somewhat faint . d- i find this beer to be extremely drinkable .  cloudy , dirty orange color .  its very smooth and velvety , very nice .

s- wheat , citrus , some grass . reminds me a little bit of some freshly baled hay -- sweet . t- very crisp , assertive hop notes that slide easily into citrus .  otter creek turns out some very drinkable beers , but often the brewery has been short on experimentation . unexpected notes of grapefruit and light burnt sugar open the nostrils . the taste is richly satisfying yet not overpowering , with a good balance of malt and hops . mouthfeel is quite good - in this case , a little bubbly , a little syrupy - and in all this is a beer one could drink at length .  the taste and mouthfeel is where this beer shines . thick , smooth and creamy with a combination of milk and dark chocolate with just a hint of licorice .

aroma is mild , too mild , but i pick up on dark roasted malts , cocoa , light caramels , ans very german-smelling hops . tastes better room temp , smells better too as it warms .  appearance : pours an opaque bronze with a thin bubbly head that quickly disappears smell : a strong burst of malt and a bit of hops on the finish taste : toasted malt dominates , but there is a subtle spicy finish not apparent in the aroma .  the mouthfeel is dead-on creamy .

aroma- not much aroma , lightly floral . taste- floral , not bitter enough for my taste mouthfeel- smooth drinkability- high , odd aftertaste , not sure if i want more herbs or less in this beer .  dark brown hue with slight mahogany tints when held to the light . little head , which settles to a cream ring .  m : remarkably full bodied and smooth but it does n't have any stickiness , carbonation did it 's job , excellent .

smell : overall very mild caramel , brown sugar , and pine cones .  pours a deep amber color with garnet highlights and a thin head that falls quickly .  the mouthfeel is great on this one too , effervescent and full at the same time .

this beer is great , it is really drinkable and similiar to a beer i love by dogfish head. , it pours brown ( obv ) and isnt too thick though , which makes it nice and drinkable . nice caramelly roasted malts and color , try this one if you are into nut browns or similair types .  appearance - pours a festive reddish amber .  mouthfeel is very thick and chewy , silky and long lasting on the palate , near perfect .

interestingly , taste is unlike the smell ... and that 's a good thing . aroma is typical lager , run-of-the-mill beer .  eye candy : pours a transparent amber . plenty of rising carbonation . fizzy thin head , klacing lasted throughout session . otherwise , autumn is perfect for the fall , drinkable from early sept untill the snow starts a flying .  exactly how i like my stouts to feel -- heavy and chewy .

yet anothe winner from rogue , pours a deep amber with a big head , aroma is faint , taste is bold spice and nice toasty malt , almost peppery , delicious . mouthfeel is pefect as seems to be the case with all rogue brews . a superb amber ale , right up there with red rocket ale in my opionion , a very enjoyable brew .  poured from 750ml bottle into tulip glass . a : dark copper , head is generous and frothing but does n't live very long and leaves almost no lacing .  very big and chewy mouthfeel

i was n't able to pick up a great deal of aroma , only slight hints of malt .  i poured it into a glass and it had a small white head that disappered quick . it poured a very light golden color . while the beer was sitting on the table i looked down at it , the bottom of the glass was almost clear as water . it was n't intense .  lush , creamy mouthfeel , that really could n't improve at all .

aroma is quite subdued . subtle citrus and toasted malt about sums it up . taste follows suit , but offers a bit more .  2010 vintage : appearance : brownish amber color , crystal clear , small 1 finger head with no lacing and little retention .  perfectly carbonated with an amazing mouthfeel .

s : had no conception this was a strong ale . i found the smell to be mild with some fairly noticeable hop notes . t : hoppy but not overpowering . d : another reviewer noted a `` double pilsner '' and i think this is dead on . good thing i only had one .  appearance : rich amber red hue . no head whatsoever . poured very smoothly out of the bottle with good amount of sediment .  super thick mouthfeel .

dont really pick up much of an aroma , some malts , some hops , but not much really . great balanced taste of malts and hops .  pours a thick deep black with a very thin tan head . no retention , no lace .  the first thing i noticed actually was the incredible mouthfeel .

aroma of caramel , sweet malt , some alcohol , mild nuttiness and not much of a hop component . wow , flavor is suprising given a fairly unassuming aroma . a pretty decent to heavy hop bitterness gives way to a fabulous hop backbone and a floral hop flavor , with slight spiciness and maybe a hint of pepper .  2004 vintage pours cloudy light brown with a few bubbles , but no head retention to speak of .  smooth as hell , perfect weight and carbonation .

s-the nose is light , nutty roasted malts with hints of herbal ester in the back . t-the taste is more full , lots of nutty flavors up front , roasted bread rolls , notes of dough , lightly roasted malt , faint herbal hop in the back .  small craft warning is a hazy golden lager with a somewhat diminishing , soft and splotchy , white head .  mouthfeel is sublime . kind of like a benign dreamy tingling that coats the palate evenly .

s - this brew primarily has a fruity nose with hints of apple and grape , along with a bit of spice , mild hops and sweet caramel malt . aroma is a little muted due to the cold serving temperaure . t - fruity , sweet , spicy , hoppy .  a decent sized white head that dissipates quickly over a macro-brew-looking yellow-clearish beer . not a great appearance . but i really , really enjoyed this one despite its underwhelming appearance .  mouthfeel is absurdly rich and creamy , silky smooth and slurpalicious . ) it 's the best feature of this brew . i mean , i like the taste , love the mouthfeel , and would enjoy having two or three of these , but that abv is on the high end .

nose is slight with hints of fruit , apple in particular . mouthfeel is very carbonated with a light citric tingle .  appearance- poured a cherry , dark brown color with almost no head ! strange .  the mouthfeel of this bastard makes the beer for me -- incredibly soft and smooth for strong ale , probably the result of the oaking .

a 1.5in foamy head builds as i pour-swish-pour-swish-pour my way through the last 4 ozs . lots of cloves and bread in the nose , but just as dominant is the smell of bier . perhaps a bit of citrus as well . the first few pulls are sublime , with big mouthfeel and a wonderful orange citrus mid palate .  very drinkable.it is refreshing to have a microbrewey beer , that is not that bitter , and very drinkable.gets you very drunk.be careful because the alcohol creeps up on you with this beer.tasted citrus.i also tasted a bit of nutmeg in the aftertaste.this beer is very easy to drink.exceptional drinkability . this is the quintessential summer ale.a light , very drinkable , however , complex enough to be a microbrewery beer.i highly recommend this beer . this is a good recommendation to the general public.inasmuch as this beer is drinkable and light , many people will enjoy this . moreover , what is cool about recommending this beer , is that many people are not aware of this beer and micro beer 's in general.this was a perfect find on a june saturday , great beer to have at a high school or college graduation party.this is a great party beer , and will generate conversation at a graduation party , because numerous people have not heard of brooklyn , even suprisingly , in new york .  mouthfeel : smooth and creamy . alcohol warmth .

s - herbal hops , sweet fruit and graininess ; feels a little light in the nose t & m - hop bitterness nicely balanced with malts .  a - pours a clear light amber . a 1/2 inch white head forms into a thin layered collar .  the mouthfeel is smooth , thick , and creamy .

very faint smell . medium body , medium carbonation . easy to drink for such a dark and strong ale .  it pours pale , cloudy gold with a thin near-white head that really does n't hang around to party .  this has an excellent mouthfeel .

smell : very sweet aroma with a caramel note to it but really very weak in the nose . very impressive flavor for a beer with such a weak aroma . mouthfeel : smooth , clean on the palate with a nice roastiness that lasts on the palate even after the beer is gone . aside from the weak smell i was very impressed with this beer .  pours a murky brown with a thin ring , not the most attractive beer at this point .  high level of carbonation with tons of tingle on the tongue . another excellent beer from ommegang .

not much on the nose here , just an openness that has some light roasty tones and dryness to it . some small phenol and sweet notes sneak in as it warms . easy , clean feel , medium bodied , nice mild little sweetness and roasty tone . not much for the nose but it makes up for it with a nice , easy going pace with flavors and body .  served chilled in a raftman tulip . appearance : murky reddish brown topped by a small light tan head . very little retention and no lacing , though i suspect this is ok for the style .  the mouthfeel was the best part : silky smooth and creamy thick ; a perfect accompaniment to dessert .

aroma - not much of aroma . taste - cola and lightly fruity flavors . nothing amazing , but nothing to be shy about .  poured into my guinness 20 oz glass , no idea when this was bottled ... there is no date listed on the bottle a-pale orange color with a small inch head s- sweet pale malt , flowery and fruity ( citrus ) hops t- very flowery , earthy , oily hops with a subtle citrus fruit taste .  the mouthfeel is amazing , thick and solid with a lingering savory finish .

hard to get a decent aroma - i 'm brewing right now so i will give it a average . fruity , earthy , a bit smokey and roasty .  pours dark brown , small tan head quickly fizzes away to a thin ring .  if you have to choose buy the triple , but as stated earlier this beer has a wonderful silky smooth mouth ... great feel for those who have an oral complex ...

decent german pils a- clear golden color with a nice fluffly head that leaves great lacing s- floral , medicinal , and metallic smells coming from this .  appearance was a bit light in color and with less head than i would 've expected , but you do n't taste with your eyes , so i 'm willing to forgive that this beer is not terribly photogenic .  so very soft on the palette - really a unique mouthfeel , just velvety smooth .
s - first impression is sweet malt and diacetyl .  it is a medium brown brew with an ivory head .  the mouthfeel is a true hallmark of this beer .

found this ipa in hillsboro oregon in the fred meyer two days before thanksgiving bought the whole 12 pack cause the parents in from out of town were paying , so why not . this beer was good , a good session ipa not too bitter more like a pale ale , good color and taste , although not hoppy enough for me .  a- pours a very pale straw yellow with a pretty white head that quickly dissipates .  mouthfeel is rich and creamy .

had on-tap at the red lobster in hickory , nc . nose was a bit sweet but there really was n't much there .  cloudy straw colored brew the a decent head and a bit of lace sticking as i drink .  m - perfect . exactly how a dipa should be .

a touch phenolic in the aroma , but not too much so . slightly bready and grainy with an undercurrent of malt sweetness . a faint suggestion of pear . the most impressive thing about the beer was a sparklingly clean finish - actually made my mouth feel clean .  it pours a clear amber color ? ? ?  extremely satisfying in this regard .

the smell was very modest and faintly malty .  i would prefer the appearance to be a little more hazy & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; but this stuff comes from germany so i guess these guys know good beer & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; the smell is reminiscent of banana i do n't get too much clove to it & gt ; & gt ; i also ge an earthy smell too & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; it tastes just like it smells & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; very easy to drink & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; watery mouthfeel not my favorite beer style but excellently true to style !  mouthfeel is about perfect , and the body is about perfect for a bock style .

smell - nuts , caramel , malt , some hops .  not much in terms of head , and what is sits atop a body of dark ruby . ahhh , lifts the nostrils into the heavens and beyond into the great void of ecstasy .  very light carbonation and a perfect body for a porter , combined with what i have already mentioned , makes this a very drinkable proposition .

a translucent orange body , sorta lie copper or a slightly lighter orange blossom honey . a solid malty body , chewy and a bit hoppy , hell of a lot better than the nose . this is a solid english pale ale , solid body of hops and malts , nothing to let you down initial taste is a bit bitter with mostly malts .  a shy color of inbetween orange and yellow . a nice foamy head that goes very fast , nice carbonisation as well .  mouthfeel : truly phenomenal creamy medium body with the slightest touch of syrup likeness .

s- there really is n't much of a smell , but there is a slight metallic smell , with a bit of a slight acid smell . as this warms up its more of a sour cabernet sovereign .  the beer pours dark , not much head exists but enough to know the beer has bubbles .  mouth : velvety good . nice water . sweet , full , but not thick . medium to full bodied .

the smell is very boring , some mild piney hops and presumably cedar , and definitely did n't impress me as i tilted the glass back for the first time . unfortunately for all other ipas , the standard to me is pliny and it 's pretty damn hard to come close to pte in drinkability .  - pours a nice cloudy hay yellow with a little orange glow to this murky wheatie looking brew . minimal large bubbly white head quickly dissipating to little to no foam at all.. left looking a touch watery.. which really is kind of expected from the style.. though it 's still rogues pacman yeast which is used in just about everything of theirs .  mouthfeel : true german feeling on this beer . medium viscosity , rolls across the palate smoothly and is perfectly carbonated . great overall feel and authenticity .

aroma is some spice , toffee .  a : pours very thick , big head with lots of lacing . color is a deep brown , very cloudy , little chunks of sediment dancing around making it look like apple cider fresh off the press .  ( m ) - this is ridiculously smooth despite its hop dryness and woody bite . great carbonation level and balance .

the aroma was light as only some malts were detectable . overall a very nice brew that was very flavorful but not overwhelming for the food .  12oz bottle , no date , in sa glass a : black with a one finger tan head that goes to ring rather quick s : roasted malts , espresso , oats and a little chocolate t : coffee , faintly bitter chocolate like bakers m : full body , little carbonation quite creamy d : enjoyable could have more than one .  mouthfeel : perfect mouthfeel .

aromas include coffee , some cocoa , and some berries . it 's not highly intense , leaving very little of a mark . overall , this is a highly drinkable , highly refined porter .  a_pours a medium golden brown with a minimal off white head with little retention or lace .  there 's a fair amount of carbonation that you feel in the swallow .

citric , fruity aroma . flavor is dominating by a surpsingly nice fresh , leafy hop flavor throughout the sip , undergirded by amaltiness which starts off sweet and develops a toasty , biscuity character toward the finish .  it has a beautiful rusty reddish brown color and tan head but it comes of as too soapy looking .  m : the best part of the beer . very creamy while still having a touch of that hop thickness you want .

the smell did n't give much away other than chocolatey malt and hops , so when i took the first sip i was surprised and utterly pleased . notes of fruit , a little nutty with a slightly bitter spicy hop aftertaste .  not very much head on this one , but a little lacing .  one of the best mouthfuls ever !

smell here is n't of really much . perhaps a bit of creaminess . it 's just kind of `` beery '' . an easy drinker ... at this low abv , you could drink these seemingly all day .  tomos watkin osb pours a deep amber with just barely off-white two-finger foamy head .  the mouthfeel was creamy and medium-bodied with light , soft carbonation .

when smell is present , it is pleasant . taste=good taste .  the beer poured more of a light gold color rather than the copper that the label described . about 1/3 inch of white head that left behind a watery white lace .  the mouthfeel was outstanding , felt like a cask beer , rich , creamy , smooth .

s - lacking a bit in this department . roasted malt is about all is decernable .  a : pours a dark brown color . a thin tan head forms and recedes in an instant .  this is a big , complex , full bodied beer . the huge amounts of malts in this thing are chewy and even feel like they stick to the teeth some .

smell : a surprisingly faint aroma , which was somewhat of a turnoff since i love the big malty aroma of doppelbocks .  it pours a lovely clear caramel brown with red highlights . very little head sits on top , and what little there is disappears almost immediately .  m : creamy and delicious . everything is dead on here .

aroma is very muted . i had a hard time picking anything up at all . unique , and very enjoyable .  part of a taster flight , about a 5oz pour to a funkwerks tulip . pours a nice medium yellow with only a hint of haze , small white head that dissipates fairly quickly and no lacing .  it is dense . the mouthfeel is warm even though it was chilled . it is excellent as it warms in the glass .

s : smells like roast and acetone ... yup , that 's nail polish . ok , i 'm not very impressed with this beer so far . t : aaaahhh ! d : as long as you hold your nose , this has great drinkability .  a- pours a hazy brown color with a one inch head that dissipates leaving almost no lacing .  medium bodied , excellent mouthfeel .

s - roasted grain . bit of coffee , that 's about it .  i 've had the bottle , and there is some weird floaters in there , but they did n't bother me . there is little head and is a nice amber in color .  the mouthfeel is perfect for the style ; adequately carbonated and finished silky and creamy .

smells of noble hops and that 's really about it , pretty much standard for a german lager , i guess . tastes more bitter than i expected , and a little sweeter than i expected .  pours a cloudy brown with murky red highlights when held to light . smallish off white head dissipates quickly .  the mouthfeel is smooth and nicely done . excellent carbonation drinkability is good as well .

the first versions were too heavy on the holiday spices and every year it seems to become more and more balanced . the smell is average , relative to a xmas style beer , which are usually loaded with spice and citrus . only the slightest hint of orange comes off the beer . the taste is excellent though . the spices and fruit are at a perfect balance with the malts and hops .  the beer pours a dark copper , forming a 1/4 inch tan head . light spots of lace on the glass .  the mouthfeel on this is exceptional , so smooth will alcohol masterfully controlled .

the aromas were very muted . i picked up malt , cask , earth , and some very mild hops .  fresh batch courtesy of viggo . pours a fluffed up retaining head , with lace remaining in glass.. smooth easy creamy drink , creamy and well-malted , well-carbonated .  the first thing i notice upon the first sip is the awesome mouthfeel on this one .

somewhat light and delicate but still flavorful . very , very drinkable . hearsay is that the house yeast strain was not used in this beer which , in my opinion , is a good thing .  appearance : pale orange golden with a slight chill haze . wispy white lace lays on top . notes : in true rogue fashion , this is a hoppy beer .  the mouthfeel is thick and rich with a nice amount of bubbly to round it out . the taste is full , many-layered . . . wonderful . a little vineous though .

crazy lacing & head retention s : leafy hops , not much else t : leafy hops , biscuitty malt & some sulphuric notes , plus a bit of citrus hops up front . finishes fruity , dry , a bit chalky even & with leafy hops mf : medium bodied with low carbonation & nice balance drinks easy for the abv , wished the hops & or malt stuck out a bit more , but a solid effort , this is probably much better on cask , i 'm betting  in munich , appearance is not indicative of taste , apparently . the beer is super light , looks like a high life/budlight/corona . i loved this beer in the liter glass beer steins with a pork knuckle .  mouthfeel is perfection . perfectly carbonated and very refreshing .

not much at all in there .  a - poured a dark copper with a one finger khaki head and no visible carbonation . no retention and slight lacing .  the mouthfeel on this beer is almost perfect . a nice smooth drinkable beer .

smells of ambient pines and a touch of birch bark with a pale , white toast base . rather bland .  pours a hazy amber with a thin white head .  keeping with the chocolate milk theme , the mouthfeel is fantastic .

not a lot of aroma up front . a few quick whiffs provides a subtle hint of ginger root .  demon fish , 750 ml bottle .  the balance here is seriously excellent though , and the mouthfeel is probably the best i have encountered in an ipa , period . truly a creamy elixir , perfect carbonation .
smell was okay . juicy fruit and later cola .  despite a vigorous attempt at a pour , i got no head at all .  mf : it has a thicker mouthfeel than i expected , and it was wonderful .
little uninspiring .  a- cloudy yellow with a small white head .  this has been sitting in the cellar for about a year and i am convinced it has the absolute perfect mouthfeel .

smells very faint , alcohol and nutmeg with a bit of almond and herbal dust .  appearance : poured with a large light tan foamy bubbly head , that dissipated quickly to a thin layer leaving just about no lacing . the beer is a cloudy orange brown color .  mouthfeel - wonderful body with great carbonation and just beautifully drinkable .

it smells sweet , with pine and citrus coming through .  poured from 64oz growler into 250ml jenlain flute glass . appearance : pours a dark reddish-brown color with a small off-white head that dissipates quickly and leaves behind no lave , but some foam floating on the glass .  it 's definitely thick , but it does n't feel anywhere near as syrupy as it looks . o : this beer has a great appearance and mouthfeel .

aromas is of carmel malts.nice , but a bit weak.body is medium with a bit too much fizz for me .  a : pitch black color , no head , no lacing s : raisins , figs , sweet woodiness t : sweet oak , raisins , figs , smoky chocolate ; finishes with a nice smoky wood bitterness m : medium-thick , lightly carbonated , velvety smooth o : this did n't quite live up to the enormous hype , but it 's still a world-class beer nonetheless .  m - wonderfully full bodied , sticky , smooth . delightful .

it smells fruity sweet and alcoholic . t : the taste is initially fairly sweet , with hints of dark fruit .  12 oz bottle bought from the wine cask in cambridge , ma pours rich ruby brownish red with a nice tan head at first which disappears quickly and does not return with swirling . if it was an older old ale i would not let this effect its appearance score , but i dont think this is very old .  great mouth feel on this one . no hops or bitterness present at first , but bitter in the finish .

smell : not much here , smelled like your average porter . weak coffee scents were all i got . taste : like guinness draught with some balls .  appearance : nice cloudy golden color with a medium head .  silky smooth thick bodied with a perfect amount of light carbonation and a ridiculously long lasting , balanced tart and sweet aftertaste .

the original yuengling lagar ( which is good ) brought me to this beer and i was very impressed .  appears a hazy yellow color and a heavy pour yields a thin , large bubbled head that fades to a sheen rapidly .  the moutfeel is exceptional - full bodied and thick with appropriate carbonation .

s - a little bit faint for me , would have like to smell the aroma a little more to get a better idea of what ingredients were used to brew it . but i did get a hint of belgian yeast with a slight funk to it , sweet malts , a small whiff of raisins and oranges . did n't get much hop aroma on this one at all . t - definitely an improvement over the smell ... flavors come out a lot more to define this beer . overall a good belgian ipa , was expecting a little bit more with the a- overall rating but a solid beer from flying dog no doubt !  finally got some last night on tap at mad mex . looks average , served in a snifter , no head , mild lacing .  first gulp of this was outstanding.. nice creamy , mouthfeel to it that just bombards your mouth with sweet , delicious beer flavor .

very smooth pale ale . probably one of the most mellow ales i have had in a while .  pours an incredibly viscous murky brown with very little to no head or lacing .  mouthfeel : a smooth sugary viscous mouthfeel that is balanced nicely by the carbonation .

-- slight smell of caramel , even slighter smell of fruit . i had no expectations whatsoever and will definetally try more of this style .  light golden color ; a little lighter than expected . smells hoppy ( citric , very grapefruit-like ) with an underlying sweetness . hops are very flavorful ( citric ) and also bring a decent bitterness , but are never harsh at any point . very tasty and drinkable beer that packs a punch .  wonderful body .

there is the light smell of caramel along with a whiff of alcohol ( which is a surprise considering the abv is not terribly high ) .  a pour down the center gave an initial 2 fingers of tan head , which diminished rapidly to a little foam around the edges ... a little disappointing . the dark color is n't opaque , if held to a back light . dark hues of deep red/garnet highlight the edges . no lacing either ( also disappointing ) .  mouthfeel is perfect - smooth and velvety without being clingy or cloying .

has a strong fruity citrus smell , i do n't really smell hops ... maybe slightly ... but not as much as other people say .  this pours almost black . not too much head and it went away a lot quicker than many other imperial stouts i 've had .  m : absolutely wonderful ... smooth & creamy .

s - light malt scent , and not much else .  bomber , a : pours mahogany with a small off-white head , fair retention , light lace .  full bodied with creamy carbonation and a lingering sweet licorice finish .

no discernable aroma at all - kind of weird .  pours like a pale ale , orange/amber with just a bit if white head . no lace . it 's a chili beer , who gives a damn .  m - perfect . it 's velvet on the tongue .

smell is lightly malted and a bit sweet ... not unpleasant at all .  the body of the liquid was hazy , but i would hesitate to call it cloudy . as the head subsided , it left a very sticky lacing on the edges of the glass that looked like bar soap froth on a wash cloth . average for the style , but nice never-the-less .  mouthfeel : the mouthfeel is outstanding . it sparkles just enough to give the palate a good tickle , but not so much that it scrapes away all of its flavor .

the aroma is malty and sweet with a decent amount of spice and just a hint of hops . fairly malty and somewhat uneventful but still pleasant . very sweet with more malt and lots of spice and fruit : orange and cinnamon , nutmeg , cardamom .  appearance : poured with some off white foamy head that dissipated quickly after leaving almost no lacing at the top of the glass .  it 's wonderful . alcohol tingles a little in the mouth and it 's certainly present in the aroma but buried 'neath the fruity yeast . expertly woven into the beery fabric of this brew .

the nose is slightly floral , but to be honest , i failed to detect much .  a - completely opaque black , lets no light through . head is a very light brown that settles at a film . lacing is average .  light carbonation , rich smooth mouthcoating sensation from the oatmeal .

it had a faint grassy , hoppy smell . the initial taste was some bitterness with a touch of citrus .  since i have said it for all of the other beers i 've reviewed in this category , i will say it for this one as well : pours a clear , piss-yellow color with a small white head . head disappears quickly and leaves no lacing whatsoever . it 's my first asian beer , but when comparing with any of the american and mexican macros and even a lot of the europeans , this is top class .  mouthfeel is intensely smooth and velvety , creamy and luscious . lactic milk sugar contributes a boatload of palate-smudging heft . although it 's not one for sessioning , it has a sublime quality that makes you savor every sip .

750ml caged and corked popped the cork with little trouble . most , strong dark ales have a slightly more scarlet color . husky , corn-like , slighty witte-like nose belying the yeasty belgianness of the beer . despite the nose , i would definitely drink this again .  stone ruination ipa pours with a frothy off-white head which fades in a few minutes .  mouthfeel : deliciously smooth with a nice , crisp finish . the high alcohol content gives it a nice warmth as well .

the aroma is of muted hops and barley . there is n't really much going on in the nose . after smelling this beer i thought it would be rather bland but the flavors pop off the tongue . i would n't call any 8.7 % alcohol beer extremely drinkable , but this is exceptional .  poured into a piraat tulip glass . has a 1cm golden head with but does n't linger with some mild lacing .  a bit astringent . fantastic , full body with a very creamy feel -- pretty impressive .

aroma is very yeasty and bready . nothing really outstanding here , but a pretty solidly made beer .  pours with zero carbonation , and not as thick as expected . no head retention and has a dark brown body .  mouthfeel : excellent light and crisp mouthfeel which is perfect for this style .

sexy stuff . smells of roast malt and cocoa . very faint , should be stronger .  my first brew from four friends , on-tap at flying saucer charlotte served in a standard pint glass a dark amber with a thin quickly diminishing head .  nice caramel aftertaste held on the tongue by the thick mouthfeel . creamy thick mouthfeel and modest carbonation .

the aroma is hoppy more than anything else . i pick up earth tones with a roasty malt background .  pours a solid finger of light tan head over a cloudy yellow copper liquid . looks like a wheat beer . no sediment was in the bottle .  mouthfeel is medium bodied and smooth . an excellent feel .

i do not like coffee i love the smell but the taste is lost on me , but this should not be feared by non coffee lovers .  murky amber with a golden hue . very thin , patchy white head .  mouthfeel is very delicious with some creamy notes but some nice crisps and sharp grassy hop notes .

smell is a little off out of the bottle - a bit glassy , but the mouthfeel and drinkability are high .  a- cloudy amber body and a small off-white head ( barely any head ) s- sweet grapes , some sweet bready malts t- follows the nose ; at first sweet dark fruits , sweet malts and there 's some wheat body m- medium body with light carbonation and it 's almost syrupy o- i dig the style and this a good overall beer .  mouthfeel is great . just the right level of thickness here .

foam didnt leave lace it left a coating of thick shaving cream , very nic ! s-dominated by sweet caramel malts with low floral/ citruy hops .  appearance - this is peculiarly shiny and clear , almost a bright orange , with little head .  a festive arrangement with great depth mouthfeel : really nice - creamy and complex drinkability : good

i definitely smell some sweet notes . t- tons of stuff in this one .  hazy apricot-looking color , left a creamy light tan coating after the clean-up of the initial opening of the beer , left some spotty lacing and some slight traces of carbination .  full bodied and silky .

nice beer . not a great saison , but a very good one . not the funkiest saison , but i kind of like that . almost a saison/belgian pale ale cross .  here goes ... i bought the beer , a single bottle , in a grocery store in oristano , sardinia ( italy ) . does n't match the bottle at the top of the page , but it does say `` stout '' and it 's strong @ 7,7 % , so we 'll call it the ceres extra strong stout . enough background .  the alcohol is kept well in check allowing the finish to cascade over the palate with a ton of character and wonderful texture . strong , long finish .

edit & lt ; this is actually a review for `` guinness extra cold , '' ( that 's right - they were actually bragging about how cold a stout was ) which was damn near ubiquitous in otherwise decent pubs throughout the uk when i was there in the summer of 2001 . guinness extra cold is basically the same as what one often gets when having a guinness in an american bar . oddly enough , when i was in england two years ago this was the only kind of guinness i found in the pubs i ventured into .  my first ballast point . a- hazy dark gold topped with dog slobber .  initially the softness of the carbonation and the sweetness of the fruity flavors makes it like a sweet soda ( can anyone remember tahitian treat ? again with the yeast character and the near rancid presence ( the brett i presume ) , yet the overall soft flavors and soft feel are greatly appealing and enjoyable . the light , fine and bubbly carbonation brings an element of childhood fun to the drink ( how about fizzies , anyone remember that ) as it brings a tickle to the nose and tongue . light overall feel and great softness . soft and light and tasty ( again in a soda pop manner ) .
