nice and warming . slight roasted malt flavor to it as well , but overall pretty sweet aroma .  ca n't really knock this beer for it 's appearance , it looks pretty good .  m : watery , very light-bodied , body of a light lager .

s - lightly minerally aroma , dark , malty cocoa .  appearance : black which shows a clear ruby when backlit . had a creamy tan head that left a little bit of lacing .  it tasted mostly like water with a very light toffee/sweet taste in the back of the tongue . that 's it . it was very drinkable in the same way water is drinkable . when a brewer wants you to chill his beer , there must be a issue with the flavor at cellar temps . i ca n't believe some people consider this to be the flagship for the style .

the smell is also quite pleasant and interesting . apple skins , lemon zest , belgian candi sugar , complex alcohols , malt backing , and dry-ish . it is a terrible combination .  it looks good in the glass a hazing orange with a nice white head .  the mouthfeel is pretty thin and watery .
the aroma was sweet almost grapelike .  a : a nice clear bright yellow .  mouthfeel is thin .

good head s : roasty , fruity , over all not bad t : garbage .  pours a dark brown with hints of amber and ruby , a good two fingers builds up on the pour and leaves light lacing down the glass .  2.5 m thin , with only the grain tastes and the slightest stickiness keeping it from being water itself .

the smell was good , but the taste disappointed me greatly ; grassy and semi-sweet fruit immediately fades to a bland , watery , weak aftertaste of very mild hops .  pours pale yellow and settles light amber in the glass . impressive , frothy head .  the mouthfeel is very watered down like an american pale ale but i thought the pumpkin taste was enjoyable .

smell-a nice nutty and sweet aroma . nice hints of roasted malts and caramel .  it 's appearance is fine with a nice amber color and decent head .  i must say this beer is best on tap as everywhere i 've tried it otherwise all of its carbonation seems to be non-existant .

o : the beer smells great , but pales in other categories , especially taste , which is a terrible place to have the weakest link .  black with brown highlights and an enormous soapy light tan head that leaves scattered patches of lacing .  pretty easy to drink with a light , watery mouthfeel .

smells of citrus and ginger , very faint cloves & cinnamon there as well , very nice . the taste is very clean .  i really enjoy most st offerings a -- nice amber/copper color s -- very surprising nutty aroma .  mouthfeel is watery . this style needs more body - the maltiness is there , but there is very little roasted character & not enough creaminess .

well , it smells pretty good at least .  it shows a bone-white head with heavy lace , and a sassy , vivid yellow color with low co2 .  the mouthfeel is this beer 's weakest point . also , it feels a bit heavy on the palate and is almost syrupy .

i like it . t : bitter pine hop flavor hits first with a little bit of relief from the malt , but it never really helps balance the beer altogether .  pours a nice light gold colour with light fluffy head .  the mouthfeel was flat and very dissapointing .

well balanced aroma . t/m - medium bodied , plenty of carbonation .  dark dark brown in color similar to almost all stouts .  taste is weak , almost watery , has to be drank ice cold or has a taste like vomit . bottom line is compared to other cheap beers pbr excels in taste , quality , and conveniently the price , 7 bucks a 12 pack .

it smells sweet and floral , but not too strong .  pours a jet black colour with no difference whatsoever when held to the light .  pretty nice . the body is as thin as water . that leads to a very drinkable beer , actually , since it goes down ... well , like water .

the smell actually has a nice deep roasted malt aroma that dominated the nose , much stronger than i would have though , slightly sweet with a cocoa presence .  appearance : this pours a maple brown , nearly mahogany , with an eggshell colored head that retains nicely . strangely light appearance for a double cda , though .  good for a lager , but way too much carbonation really throwing this beer off .

s - earthy , estery fruit with guava fragrance , slight anise notes .  appears a dark amber/red color . with a small white head .  the mouthfeel was watery , the body medium/light and the carbonation average .

the aroma instantly improved my mood . wonderful complexity . dark fruit , alcohol , plum , rich malts , yeast , a little tawny port , some light diacetyl , and little bit of cola . again , nice nose , but overall this was a huge disappointment .  a - hazy ( for a pale lager ) yellow with a big frothy head that lingers .  mouthfeel was very watery and not smooth in the slightest .

the aroma is very nice . taste : sickly sweet . drinkability : the aroma is very promising , but the sweetness destroys it , this went right down the drain - and i had wanted to enjoy it as it was a pain to get .  pours a deep ruddy brown with a thin layer of head that leaves a massive amount of lacing .  i 'm going to have to go against the gimmick and with the style here , the mouthfeel just is n't there . i 'm not impressed at all , it 's like a half flat beer that you 've left on your desk whilst reviewing a beer and forgotten about it only to come back to it 30 mins later . the shining point of this beer is it 's drinkability .

4.0 s : surprisingly grainy , which i like . roastiness , some toffee , and a touch of coffee . fairly simple , but pleasant nonetheless .  served in a stone vertical epic glass that can be described as stemless martini-like . pours a dark golden-copper color with a good white head and some lacing .  the mouthfeel on this one fluctuates but it has one of the worst finishes i can recall in a beer . the thin body and soda-like carbonation ( and some wheaty texture ) save this some , but the finish is just harsh . artificial flavor , sticks to the teeth , chewing on cardboard , something is wrong here finish to the mouthfeel .

smell- roasty and malty with much hop presence . hops are pretty strong , but not overpowering .  looks kinda cool .  i 'm gon na have to say the mouthfeel is what keeps this from being very drinkable . it felt almost like flat soda .

the aroma was gingerbread spice and cinnamon spice with some light caramel maltiness . almost the aroma of allspice one finds in a pumpkin beer .  reviewed 2/7/2008 ( bottle ) : pours a golden yellow colored body , with a huge creamy white head , lasting , with okay lacing .  water with a little spice and alcohol . the smell is the best part with mainly cinnamon . the taste is one dimensional cinnamon with a super light water taste on the back . no malt or pumpkin to be found . not a good beer nor a good pumpkin ale but if someone handed me one i would have no problem finishing it . also you could down 3 or 4 no problem and being $ 6 a 6 pack you ca n't beat that .

smell is quite pleasant . tastes to match with a heavy booze flavor and finishes cloyingly sweet .  stroh 's in a can , why not let 's do this ... appears a golden clear bubbly quote , unquote beer look to it with large heavily carbonated bright white head floating above body dwindling at a moderate pace leaves some nice patches of sporadic lacing around my duvel chalice ... sorry duvel .  the mouthfeel is way to under carbonated and watery for the style .

aroma is fruity with white grapes , brewady yeast and a bit of cloves .  it pours a golden color with a bodacious foamy head . the white foam across the top almost has the consistency of pudding .  thin to medium mouthfeel with zero carbonation -- lifeless .
nose is cocoa powder off the bat , with sweet coffee .  looks pretty good in a pint glass .  mouthfeel very thin , almost light-bodied , and lacking in bitterness .

s- it does have a nice smell of oranges .  pours out to a slightly hazy light amber with orange accents , forming a large light beige head after a vigorous pour . head is sea-foam in consistency and has ok retention with sparse lacing .  the mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and watery .

the description had me sold on this particular brew . i had spent the week camping in new york and in stowe- so drinking this seemed fitting . i felt like i had the remains of a campfire in my mouth . this brew is not for everyone , but i think it is worth trying .  once the cheap gold foil is removed and the cap pried off , it pours a very clear deep purpley ruby with a slightly pink head that laces nicely . looks really neat .  not so much the taste as it had a good belgian style wheatiness to it but the body was extremely thin and almost watery . i was looking for more in the way of the mouthfeel .

nose smells like yummy cherries , the kind of nose you get from a cherry infused cider .  the pour into 180 ml chimay chalice delivers a garnet reddish-brown body overlain by light tan head that slowly sets to a bubbly island encircled by an elevated peripheral ring .  the mouthfeel is disappointing with absolutely no carbonation and mild flavors lingering around . overall , i could have possibly gotten a flat beer but this beer had potential ( when carbonated ) but it didnt come through in my bottle .

the aroma hints at more of a tart belgian ale than a ami wheat or even s witbier . the atste is mildly tart , this is ok becasue it 's so differebt from what i 'm used too .  looks can be deceiving . this beer looked fine , sporting a rich copper hue .  very watery . the mouthfeel was thin and watery as well .
smell : raisin and roasted malt .  black pour with a two tone mocha head that is several fingers thick .  mouthfeel is thin , macro thin .

s : dominated by citrus , get a lot of tangerine , citrus , pineapple , and an earthy belgian yeast kick , light pepper .  nice to see this on tap in boston , it is n't available everwhere . nice thick head that lasted throughout the pint , decorated my glass all the way down . medium copper in color , with a clean slightly soapy smell .  m : bitter , almost no carbonation , light to medium body .

it smells quite fruity ( apples ) and a bit astringent .  a : this beer pours a nice deep , translucent , bronze color with a khaki colored sudsy head .  this is very much like corona . not as good as miller light .

it poured a very nice clear copper color , and while it did not have much head it looked good and it also had a nice aroma , however , it had one of the strangest tastes i have had in a beer .  i poured the beer into my favorite laser etched pint . the head is a little more bubbly than the stout , but other than that it looked like a pint of the draught .  mouthfeel is also watery with not much body and no carbonation but essentially pretty drinkable due to the fact that is just resembles colored water .

looks a lot more like a lager than an ipa ... there is some wispy retention on the glass . smells appetizing -- i get mango from the esters and citrusy hops . i like the way the fruit aromas mix with the graininess of this beer in the nose , but less so on the tongue . as a grad student on a budget , i 'll continue to buy it as long as it 's on sale , though i should really just make 10 gallons of true ipa and stop supporting mediocre `` craft '' brewing ...  served in a bruery tulip . pour yields a garnet-colored brew that is almost bordering on purple . good tan head and a bit of lacing as it goes down .  the lack of body really disappointed me . while surprisingly drinkable , this beer needs to be heavier to match the taste , so more body and more alcohol are needed .

hopscent is sweet/floral with a good bit of sugary malt aroma as well . so much for the good will built up by the appearance and smell . the finish is so astringent and gummy that it almost completely takes away from any positives achieved by the consistency and carbonation of the drink .  it pours a very active pale gold , with a thick , three-finger head that imparts nice lacing - looks kinda like a hefe or wit .  m - weak and thin . lifeless .

s - fruity and sweet and alcoholic . very different than a raspberry lambic .  bomber , a : pours black with a medium mocha coloured head . good retention , light lace .  a nice chocolatey finish that lingers for a while on the palate is the best part about this beer . m : poor .

spicey , fruity , and perfumey nose .  after having and really liking the belgium red i figured that i would find this one out of this world , as i like raspberries far more than cherries . it is thick too . the pour has a pinkish head as well . i guess it just tastes too real -- well with the addition of far too much sugar .  mouthfeel is rather thin for a scotch ale .

aroma : dark roasts produce mild dark chocolate and black coffee robust tones with an air of nuttiness and tart cherries blended in there .  it looks pretty nice .  it was ice cold thanks to the cooler and that made it tasty . watery but that 's alright because your not expecting anything but that from bud ice .

s ) roasted grain . coffee bean . earthy - dirt .  pours a large white head with fair retention and some lace .  appearance : dark amber color with a nice 1/2 '' off white head ... unfortunately this reminded me of a pop on the pour smell : pine , hops , citrus taste : kinda watery , slight citrus ( maybe cascade hops ) mouthfeel : thin drinkability : could do two in a night , but i 'd rather drink something that tastes better

dusky crimson-glinting brown adorned with a fat gob of buttercreme suds . rum-steeped fruit nose , a la fruit punch with cherries , pineapples , and apples , then backed with a stanch vanillin oak character . begins with a tepid fruitiness . again with the cherries , pineapple , and apples . yeast come in and sprinkles slate and sandalwood earthiness . it leaves a semi-acrid and astringent burnt coconut essense mixed with a tannic and lingering sense of black cherry skins as it rides out forcefully vinous . light bodied , but it feels fatter with some element of clinginess . the barrel-aging really just ruins this .  pours a deep black color with a thick brown colored head and a little lacing all around .  for the level of alcohol , there is hardly any hotness at all and a bizarrely watery and light body for a barleywine . could also stand some more hops , as i could hardly detect any at all .
sweet flowery aroma and a spicey sweet taste with late alcohol warmth .  the beer has an overall nice appearance .  mouthfeel is weak and watery .
s : very nice . clearly a stout . lovely sweetness .  a- nice deep-amber body with a good head and great retention .  m : light carbonation with a very light watery body .

smells very musky with an almost barleywine note .  pours from the bottle into an imperial pint with an amber color and a decent head .  aside from that , the taste , like the smell , is unremarkable mouthfeel is borderline watery .

s : a fruity smell predominates , some citrus notes , but a cherry and raisin aroma is stronger . a mildly piny hop presence is there as well .  pours a brown , yellow , orange color with a good white head .  no finish , the faintest body , texture is nil , nothing to recommend it at all .

huge fruity nose with lots of pineapple . pretty sour which also makes me think it may have been a bad bottle . hugely disappointing considering how much i had heard about hair of the dog .  decent retention but great lacey webbing even on a sultry summer evening .  body is way too thick , sweet , and syrupy .
an aroma of banana , cloves , spices and hops .  the beer came in a handsomely labeled bottle , and poured out dark red , with a decent sized foamy off white head .  watery and flat in my mouth .

s. bananas with some caramel sweet malt . d. i wish this tasted more like it smelled . there was a lot going on that did n't quite jive .  a : rbb is mahagony and crystal clear , with a white head that holds up , but is rather thin .  the mouthfeel is poor . it seems to lack enough carbonation .

smells pretty good when present .  the beige compact , firm foam is two finger thick .  head falls into the liquid way too quickly and seems to look more like bubble bath suds that the typical beautiful belgian head . certainly is the high point of the beer . alcohol comes a little too strong on the palate and seems to take over the other flavors . flat on the tonque . outrageously overpriced and overrated .

aroma is rich in smoky , roasted chocolate malts , and fresh brewed coffee ( better java flavor than some java stouts ) .  a - orange type of color with a nice head .  the mouthfeel is a lowlight , though , with a very thin , watery body being punctuated by small , prickly bubbles .

good . t : watery banana upfront with some bitter sugared malts .  on-tap at bruery provisions the pour is bright orange in color with a finger of white head .  here we go : a - opaque reddish-brown , small head with minimal lacing s - malts , hint of hops , not much else t - much like the aroma , mildly sweet malts , faint hop bitterness with weak coffee m - thin , a bit too thin for a brown ale d - no problem putting down a few if i chose to , but i do n't think i would unless it was my only alternative to bmc lagers .

sour fruit to the nose .  i love all things kirkland and am also a big fan of costco , but this beer was a genuine let-down . it pours an attractive brassy color , with a pretty nice amount of head .  m - the body is vanishingly thin and i feel the carbonation is too high for an english porter .

s - pretty good aroma . chocolate and coffee are both strong but not overpowering .  a-cloudy gold , nice white head s-fairly gross smelling , like a very tangy orange with wheat t-orange and wheat upfront that quickly fades in to a tanginess . sam adams , thank you for changing the spring seasonal to the noble pils , you still should 've left this out of the winter package and never made this again .  taste is rich and sweet , slightly nutty , but this beer really sufferes from it 's thin and watery mouthfeel .

all of the pleasant aromas of the nose have vanished leaving some nasty diacetyl and way too much breadiness .  the color was very appealing , but that was all . when i gathered the nerve to take a drink and really sink my teeth into this beer , it felt like i was drinking a beef jerky smoothie .  mouthfeel is disappointing ; thin and watery , with too much carbonation for my taste .

beer smelled like fresh bread with a fruity apricote kinda taste .  it sits golden in the glass , partially obscured by haze , and stacked high with sticky , lingering white suds .  mouthfeel is where the beer suffers . it just feels wrong . a very tasty and aromatic beer , and if you can get past or prefer the super-low carbonation level .

initial aroma of wheat dough and spices faded as beer warmed . mouthfeel was slightly tingly , yet not what i would expect from a white .  alex keeps feeding the beast ... a sexy can served in my darkness glass ... pours a super clear medium gold with about three fingers of head . the head just looks weak , watery and whispy but it actually hangs for a bit and has surprisingly full lacing ... a medium skunk aroma , rice , alcohol .  i feel like i have now experienced the true port/lost abbey experience , this is the first one i 've had that is flat ... a : pours dark brown with caramel highlights , zero head even after stiff pour , some clarity s : nose is predominantly oak and vanilla , some char quality in there , stout base takes a back seat t : vanilla and bourbon again dominate , some ashy character in there along with light notes of leather and tobacco , a bit of of boozieness on the finish mf : low carbonation is an understatement , medium body o : good flavors here , the lack of carbonation takes away from the quality a bit , for the premium price tag , i would expect carbonation .

smells very nice of a strong vanilla flavor . very strong coffee smell as well . taste is somewhat strange at first .  appalachian trail blaze brown is a clear red ale with a thin beige head that fades and leaves nice lacing .  getting some sweetness from the milk sugar too , but not a lot m- thin . flat .
nose is cherries and sour funk .  greatful red pours a amber color with strong red and light brown hues . good head and lacing .  over carbonated , watery .

dark fruit aroma with pineapple and apricots as the main smells coming through .  it poured a dark brown-copper color with a nice off-white head and good lacing .  the first thing i notice with this beer is the watery mouthfeel . the mouthfeel is terrible .

nice pils maltiness on the nose spattered with floral and spicy hop notes .  pours black with a very light tan head . nice retention and dotted lacing covers my glass .  m/d - weak and thin mouthfeel .

opening the bottle unleashed a nice orange citrus and floral aroma . the brew was a light orange color , and the white fizzy head quickly dissipated in the tulip . there was hardly any malt for a pale ale , and no real balance to the light citrus and floral hops .  appearance is very good . a nice dark red brown but not black like so many american porters . clean and transparent . dirty socks maybe ? a cheap macro would do this for you .  crisp to the point of being overdone , loads and loads of soda like carbonation . notes : ho hum , average , run of the mill , mediocre ... etc .

interesting aroma . very floral with slight hints of spice and citrus .  appearance : this was a very dark , ruby-brown lager with a light tan head . a thin layer of foam was left capping the beer , leaving a decent amount of lace behind .  body is a nip thin . a bit too still , but more carbonation would have blasted through the empty body of the beer , making it even less desirable .

aroma smelled strongly of fresh strawberries ; very nice .  pours a rather attractive light orange hue .  the beer was thin bodied and very easy to drink . for a faint tasting , macro lager it was n't too bad .

the initial aroma is promising- delivering a crisp maltiness , low-lying sweetness , and a good helping of cascade hops for a grapefruity , lightly piney aroma . fair and balanced throughout the nose . flavors is where the beer begins to give way .  the beer poured a clear medium gold color with a four finger fluffy white head that lasted awhile and left lots of lacing .  medium bodied , but watery .

aroma is malty with pleasant notes of bananas .  this nearly opaque brown pint arrived with a huge , cloudy head .  mostly smells and tastes like a lager pretending to be an ale . that hint of lager ( as in yuengling lager ) sits there in the background , but then there 's a nice hit of hops in there too . it 's odd , but not necessarily bad ( although certainly not a good american pale in any sense of the word ... it 's a cheap beer masquerading as an american pale ) . not great , but one to try if you 're tired of lager as your cheap beer for the minute .

smell is of apricots and other dried fruit , not a strong scent but definately a scent . mouth is light and crisp but a surprising bitterness to it which is enjoyable . taste is a bit grassy and still some apricot to it but not much .  the pour was highly carbonated , with thick tan , lingering head .  mouthfeel this one was clumsy and , worst of all , lacked the fluffy character of a good hefe weizen .

as expected , strong aroma of sweet oats and roasted coffee .  not sure of the age of the bottle , freshness dating might be a good idea . looked good .  feel : very thin bodied and a bit too light in body for an ipa or even an apa .

s : oranges and cream , honey , lemon , heather . d : the aroma was so promising , but overall this beer is shooting for typical and falls just shy of that .  got about an inch of head with average retention . somewhat impressed with the lacing on this one .  the body was water and medium light .

nose is weak chocolate , figs , and roasted barley .  the santa fe pale ale poured a copper-orange with an thick and creamy off-white head that laced the glass .  mouthfeel : body is thin and water and a little flat ; finsih is wet and is like drinking malt flavored water . the flavors are mild and meek , the body is super watery and does n't offer much , so i do n't feel i will be drinking this again .

aroma has that sweet peanut aroma as well as lager yeasty aromas .  appearance : hazy but clear blond with a big billowing white head . very bubbly stuff .  i was again surprised to find a very thin mouth feel dominated by carbonation which seemed to accent the minimal hops to make them more pronounced .

who woulda thunk it : ginger leads the way in the nose ... notes of caramel malts and a bit of spice , yeast round out the aroma . an intruiging ( in a good way ) smelling brew . taste takes a step back .  beer emerged from the bottle a rich golden color and offered a decent white head that then went on to leave some lacing on my glass .  mouthfeel is overly fizzy , making an already light beer even fluffier . overall , this is an interesting beer that could be very refreshing if less carbonated .

smelled great very rich and malty . unfortunantly that aroma did not carry over in the taste which was on the weak side .  appearance : it pours a rich brown colour with 1 1/2 finger white foam head .  m - syrupy , mouth coating body with an obnoxious amount of carbonation . carbonation is prickly and really too much as i feel like i ca n't taste everything because of it . it does get better the more you let it warm and let the carbonation die down .

i get a nice dose of floral and citrus hops .  my wife picked this up for me last week in nyc , i assume its fresh . poured from a bomber into an oversized snifter . produceing a 1 '' tan head . the beer is black with no light penetration . scattered thin lace left on the glass .  very light bodied , an ok mouthfeel.. just way too watery and thin , not much for taste , just some lemon zest on the after taste .

aroma is actually quite good . sweet rasberry aroma , mixed with a nice lager like smell .  orange color , looks like it might be hoppy , excited .  appearance : golden with extremely high head with low head retention smell : sublte hop aroma , taste : light and refreshing , herbal with some decent hop flavor mouthfeel : light bodied , way too much carbonation , jeez ... drinkability : great flavor belgian pale but its overcarbonated .

the first smell was of licquorice , then coffee , then dark chocolate . the flavours in the taste followed very closely to the aromas , but a whole lot sweeter .  appearance : i must say by taking a look at it , its a very pretty orange/ honey color with minimal head ... so far so good .  m - way too much carbonation for my taste .

nose is molasses and licorice with some hints of smoke ; sweet dried plums and cherries in the background . it looks like a stout . the low taste rating is simply because i did n't enjoy this beer , and i 'm very jealous of the reviewer who managed to taste this on draft because i 'm stuck with five bottles i do n't want : - )  nice color for the style .  t : cheap carbonated corn . m : if it werent for the bottle this beer would have sunk years ago .

everything from the nose is lost to sweetness , very disappointing .  looks nice . very dark brown with clear , ruby-brown edges and a thin tan cap of fine bubbles . good head retention , a bit of lacing .  mouthfeel is very flat and is not impressing at all .

the aroma is of roasted/ chocolate malts and grainy alcohol hints .  the pour on the beer was very nice , proper stout black with a thick tan head on top .  m - very thin and watery with flat carbonation .

smells nice , a bit fruity , with a refreshing effervescent quality . does smell a bit on the citrus side .  a : wow ... i must say i 'm quite amazed at the formation of the head on this thing . after it settles it leaves a 1/2in white creamy head . looks kind of like ice cream the body of the beer is black with some ruby highlights . the only thing keeping me from giving this a five is the fact that it really dos n't look like beer , more like a milkshake or something .  the body is light and really lacking .

s : smells like raspberries and cinnamon ( do n't think i 've ever smelled cinnamon that strong before in a beer ) .  drank from a bottle . i first had to rid myself of the expectations of guiness extra stout in a bottle ( what i 'm used to ) . chocolately and coffee-ish , appropriately bitter , no noticeable hops .  mouthfeel : absolutely no carbonation .

aroma is dominated by much graininess . nice golden color upon pouring .  the brown 33cl bottle ( best before 11/2011 ) was poured into a 'paderborner pilsner ' badged stemmed flute . regular lager look , clean , clear , light golden body , crowned with a snowy white head of bubbles , the head left some good lacing on the flute .  mouthfeel is very , very light -- it goes down like nothing at all .

smells heavily of booze dipped dark fruit and straight up alcohol , but not much burn .  it looks nice enough , in fact it looks pretty great . it pours very dark with nice ruby highlights on the edges when held up to light .  m - thin , a little harsh and a bit drying .

the whisky barrel smell hits you immediately , and like a ton of bricks . it continues from there , slapping you with a mouthful of roasty malt and alcohol . the nastiness continues in the aftertaste , and the best part is when you ca n't taste it any more .  pours a brassy yellow with a solid foamy head that laces the glass nicely .  the mouthfeel is flat , but predictable as there are virtually no bubbles in the glass after the first minute or so . as far as drinkability goes , i 'd save it for the hot summer days , the ballpark and the cheap 30 pack for the party .

the smell is terrific , which really surprised me after that truly lackluster performance in the pour .  tommyknockers imp nut brown a 4-4.5 somewhat aggressive pour yields a one-finger tan head above a cocoa body with orange highlights . the ring holds well and leaves spotty lace .  nose was fruity apples , peaches , apricots , but the mouthfeel was watery and very sour ... not like the lead-in on a flemish sour ... just tartly sour .

smell : ah , now we 're getting somewhere . super saturated bock aroma , fusels , brown sugar , surprisingly sharp citrus notes . as it opens up , cherry and vanilla become more assertive .  gee , i hate to write a bumming report on my favorite brewery but ... this beer taste like it got scorched at some point . big scorched coffeee tatse , and hints of molasses . very dark and again the recipe has changed from last year ( last years was very piney ) .  smells and tastes bland and grain like . almost stale . it is a good beer to party with if all your doin is playin beer pong or circle .

the aroma brings floral hops and peachy malt sweetness . it mellows as it warms bringing more palatable orange bread sensibilities but it still languishes in a sort of acrid no-man 's land .  poured a thick foamy head on a solid red body .  m- strange , slick mouthfeel with a semi dry finish .

s : smells great for a pale ale , smells like hops and hoping the taste measures up .  appearance-dark golden color , nice white head that dissapears slowly .  very sweet flavour , largely the same elements as in the aroma , but far too sugary and overwhelmingly sweet for me .

back in the aroma i am digging the rich toasty bready stuff . there is a bit of the aroma 's promise for maybe a quarter second , then , `` wham ! i would imagine that if the flavor held to the aroma this would be a nice red ale that i could drink a ton of , but this one just is n't right .  the peak one pours a dark black with mahongany highlights . it has a light brown head that quickly dissipated to a thin film and collar that laced the glass a little .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and watery with almost no carbonation .

smell - sweet cherry with a sour breath to it , almost like a flemish red . sour , most definitely sour , with a fruity aroma to it ; most likely banana . very pungent , while not bad , not very saison like .  pours an attractive deep copper with a small head .  the mouhfeel is weak , watery , thin .

nose is pleasant , full of citrus and wheat , and an undefined spiciness .  a nice carbonated tangerine orange . a thin soap-like head that laces to the glass nicely . this is a very average amber ale .  m : despite its creamy appearance , the head feels thin on the palate . the brew itself is thin and watery , especially as it warms . the carbonation barely registers .

very odd look for a dipa s : lots of citrus on the nose . grapefruit , orange and banana .  poured dark amber , clear , with a good head .  palate scraping astringency . the lack of carbonation particularly makes me wonder if i should have given this more time in the cellar to condition .

s- cinnamon scent is ever-present and festive . t- pumpkin and earthy but no hops .  it has good color , but beyond that that this ipa is not a pleasant one to drink .  mouthfeel was slightly thick and flat .

the aroma is good . it has a solid malt bill of pale and carapils malts ; even some light crystal/bisquit as well .  the only thing i liked about this brew was in its presentation . it forms a tight white creamy head , which sticks around quite well . the body is golden with a slight haze .  thin watery and light in body o - did not even reach moderate expectations of being a porter and tasting barrel aged , just not very good in my opinion .

the wheat wine here seemed to me to be just like a regular barley wine to me and my friend who split the bottle . i was thinking that it would be a nice lighter strong beer before the dinner we had but it was heavy and boozie . i have n't been able to see much of a difference between wheat and barley wines .  the pour is promising .  a - light , clear , yellow color with a thick head that dissipated quickly s - beer , cheap beer t - beer from a can , cheap beer from a can m - thin , flat , not much d - went down smooth , probably because i 'd wisely iced it down with some ice and rock salt so it would get really cold .

i wish hotd would start holding onto their bottles to give then a chance to carb up , if i was brewing , i wouldnt want to send out uncarbed bottles . the flavors are very interesting , the cherry does come through rather prominantly and has a large amount of sweetness behind it , and i think this is why the alcohol is hidden rather well , it is detectable only in some flavors and not so much in heat . the barrels come through with some oak too much not substantially so . there are alot of comparisons to a wine i could make with this actually , but i am not tomme . think of brandy angles share and decide .  appearance : clear coppery color with a rich thick white foam . plenty of persistent lacing on the glass as i drank it down , but the foam on top does eventually go to just a thin film . shame that a beer which looks so nice at first turns out to be a let down in all other categories .  mouth is thin and watery . too simple and too one dimensional and thin .

the smell was fragrant and very boozey . it wafted cough syrup memories .  a : pours a dark golden yellow with a couple fingers worth of fairly oily looking bright white head that took its time fading into a thin film that left a pretty good layer of sticky lace down the glass .  where this beer falls off is the mouthfeel ; it was like coca-cola without the carbonation . drinkability would be pretty good i guess , if you can get pas the average flavors and thin mouthfeel .

s : raisin , fig , brown sugar , classic `` american '' quad . nice smelling beer . t : big brown sugar , dark fruit , some molasses , very similar to the nose , though the agave comes out a lot more than in the smell .  the beer is beautiful golden and looks damn good but yuck w the taste ... .  mouthfeel is entirely too thin and watery .

s - nice aroma of cider ... that seems to be a recurring theme for me with this beer .  i wasnt sure i would get the $ 6.50 that i wanted so i could buy the local growler i had my eye on , and i didnt . ) the beer itself ( seen easily through the clear glass 40 bottle , ) seems darker than many other 40s like st ides and steel reserve , which boast the same 8.2 abv .  the mouthfeel is light to medium bodied and just way too thin and watery for an oatmeal stout .

fresh aroma , fruity , with notes of peach , nectarine , citrus . once a favorite , before i discovered what the revivalists among american craftbrewers have been doing with this style . apparently , the american version , bottled and draft , is weakened some for `` our '' taste , and i 'm profoundly disappointed .  a : this sour brown ale , true to its name , pours deep ruby-tinted brown , with a quickly-vanishing two-finger head that is also a rich burnt-straw-brown mahogany . maybe i 'm just not a sour beer drinker , as this is perhaps a well-crafted beer for its style , but not what i like to experience when tasting a fourteen-dollar bottle of beer .  good lacing down the glass s : coffee , sweet bready malts t : coffee , slight harsh maltiness also slight hint of chocolate m : light very thin bodied beer .

there is a lot going on here . smells kind of like red wine , also smells like a lambic . i 'm guessing the lambic aroma is really brett . the more i smell it , the more i like the smells .  pours amber with a large , white head .  m - kind of flat on the palate with very little carbonation . hop profile caught me off guard and the mouthfeel is pretty weak .

the blueberries floating in it drove the aroma of fruit in the nose , like cereal fake blueberries .  i really want to like this local brewery but something about every beer i try ends up being below average . this beer , for a stout , is great looking but the taste is something very strange .  m : thin body and light carbonation .
hoppy aroma as expected , decent amount of it i 'd say .  nice chestnut hue to it . some head with a decent carbonation level .  thin and watery .
s : molasses , toffee , caramel , chocolate .  a- has a nice amber color to it . nice and clear .  the mouthfeel is pretty sad on this one . very watery and thin .

aroma is good - coriander , peaches , a bit of pipe smoke - but a bit harsh .  poured into a snifter it forms a tan head that falls to islands . picturesque ruby red body with slow rolling carbonation .  the mouthfeel is unbalanced as if the carbonation and the liquid will not merge . for as much noise the carbonation made on opening the bottle , it seems quite on the palate .

s : very nice rich smell that is typically associated with ipa 's with a little amount of sweetness on top t : pretty decent taste but nothing that particularly blew me away .  this brew suffered from major oxidation ... we had two sixers of this and they both tasted the same ... such a shame , i had heard such good things about this dark berry brew ... i literally couldnt drink an entire bottle of the product we had due to the horrible funk taste i came across ... oh well it looked great being poured into the saskatchewan tundra ... cheers !  s. nonexistent . m. also nonexistent . just plain and unoffensive . light beer on amber side ? nothing to brag about but goes down like water . above average in it 's class .

s : hops , herbs , tangerine , yeast t : toffee , bread , flowers , lemon peel . this disappointed me a bit .  a- actually looked nice after the pour . red in appearance , nice head retension s- smell is where it really falls out .  mouthfeel is too thin for me .

aromas of chocolate , roasted malts , and very light oat . tastes of roasted malts , chocolate , oatmeal , and i was getting tin .  330ml bottle poured into a pilsner glass appearance- light and golden , bright and transparent . good 2 fingers of head , which dissipates very slowly .  not much depth at all m- lacking for a stout -- - no creaminess and it 's pretty thin overall d- wo n't seek this out again and i hope the rest of the breweries selections are better -- - really loses you in the mouthfeel

the smell is mostly citric hops , with distinct lemon notes , some sweetness like candid sugar , a hint of raising dough .  a - pours a deep gold with about two inches of foam .  the finish is lightly sweet rather than crisp , and the mouthfeel , which started out thin , ends on a watery , undercarbonated note . zywiec is an average epl , making it a below average beer in general .

mouthfeel is thin reminds me of carbonated water overall it smelled pretty good but the taste left me wanted something else .  25cl into a tulip . unexceptional head , nice lacing .  mouthfeel is overyly fizzy and thin .

s - a nice soothing floral aroma , a bit of the odor from those red annuli that come with steaks , and then there is some seltzer water .  it pours nicely and the nitro tap gives it that cool lava lamp effect .  watery mouthfeel in terms of a stout .

the nose is full of notes of raisiny notes as well as distinct hoppy character .  either a nitrous pour , a crazy looking on-tap carbonation . looks decent , dark brownish black with a very creamy off white head .  it drinks as a light beer ; it is very thin and weak , much unlike guinness .

nice . the liberator is n't quite my bag of tea .  the beer poured very dark brown with a nice tannish head .  high gravity beer , this one is king . drink alot of water when drinking or a major headache occurs . so drink with caution .

smells very different than any amber i have had but still smells good . t - i get some of the spices and hops but tastes very watered down , really disappointing .  hazy orange with a nice head .  very carbonated ... .too much .

the nose is straight up cherry . almost too much cherry .  the beer pours a clear amber with a full fluffy red tinted head .  ( m ) thin mouthfeel with some bitterness loosely gripping at the tongue , barely holding on .
the aroma was that of tart yeast and that distinc lambic mustiness .  from the bottle , it pours dark amber and clean .  horrible macro version of the style .

this is a beer that , while not having a particularly outstanding taste , does offer a unique , fruity smell . i consider it a light tasting beer with the same alcohol content as a regular lager .  one moment i think i really like bocks and then i have a bock like this , and then am not so sure .  empty , chalky mouthfeel , not much going on here .

attractive lacing . smell is a rich combination of herbs and spices , with sassafras , vanilla , and wintergreen being detected . there are others there , but i am unable to specifically identify them taste also shows lots of spices and herbs and while they combine nicely , they also have there own separate taste sensations .  pretty attractive amber with an impressive head .  the mouthfeel is astringent .

very nice .  but now , 2,500 miles from the source , and from it 's 25.4 oz oil can , i get the opportunity to try it again : poured into a stange , it 's golden color is attractive along with its well built head that does n't fizz .  mouthfeel : medium-bodied . it took much diligence to see my way to the end of this beer , and , were it not for the runaway carbonation , it could 've been far better . one to revisit , provided they clear up the carbonation issue .

i found this beer to have an interesting , complex aftertaste . i had another dark beer ( ca n't remember the name , and it 's not listed on-tap on their website anymore ) at brewery creek that did n't have any flavor at all . so i am pleased that this had a lot of flavor . it just was n't my cup of tea .  there is lots of carbonation , a head that rises a good full three fingers of light tan head . decent renention , nice lacing as it falls very thick and covers totally ... the aroma is little off , almost a generic quality to it .  m - crisp start but the finish ends up being very watery .

i had not heard of this kristalweizen style before , so i thought i was reviewing a straight wheat , but here goes . aroma is really hefty considering the low abv and general weakness of the flavor . there 's a great bit of bready yeast and a big malted wheat aroma . exactly what you would expect .  this beer has a pinkish hue , a nice color and good head formation upon pouring into a pint glass .  a thin mouthfeel and not a lot of carbonation .
smells pretty good .  poured a black color with good carbonatio and a tannish head .  mouthfeel is thin .

the aroma is very belgian with lots of sour fruit lacto , weaker raspberries and cherries , dusty basement .  it poured a dark burnt , stained woodlike amber with a quickly dissipating off white head .  the mouthfeel is light and watery , not much substance . a very watered down dunkel , i would skip this in the future .

quite a nice aroma . tastes like it smells but with a bit of sweetness . was light and crisp with a slight dryness at the end .  a ) pours nicely . golden honey , good carbonation , white 1cm head , which persists . surprisingly good start .  m : really unappealing .

a- 3 very light blonde color reminiscent of a cider , with a minimal white head which dissipates to practically nothing quickly . s- 4 the aroma of this is more like white grapes to me , similar to a wine , but the peach is definitely there in the background . it smells as if it will be refreshing ... t- 3 it is hard for me to get past the tartness of this brew .  pours a three finger cream head that fades slowly leaving a trace of lace . chrystal clear amber color . good carbonation and medium bodied .  the mouthfeel was very thin for a stout .

s : distinct and delicious aroma of butter rum leads off . honestly , this smells like angel 's share should have smelled .  pours a orange almost amber color with a less than finger head .  m - medium-thin mouthfeel with low carbonation . a bit watery , the consistency of this beer is not what i wanted . too thin , not creamy enough for me .

i was expecting this ... s- very oaky smelling with a copious amount of bourbon presence t- bourbon is overwhelming vs the sweet malts of the flat beer .  the color of this beer is quite good . light yellow with a small white head .  the mouthfeel was flat leaving a watery feel in the mouth .

light aromas of oak barrel , sweet malts , raisons , and a tad bitter sweet chocolate . i 've been enjoying the stout and ruby port mix , a.k.a velvet pussy , for some time now and imo a quality 12oz stout with a 1/2oz pour of quality port works better than ohanlons concoction .  pours a nice `` pale-golden '' yellow , nice head , that last fairly long .  that being said i want to keep track of beers i have tried and will start to try reviewing beers i drink ) from a sampler pack found at specs liquor . tastes flat to me . no alcohol taste that i can tell of and not a whole lot of flavor . goes down easy and not much of an aftertaste .

i also get a sort of hospital sanitation aroma . i always think sahti smells very interesting and inviting as well as completely authentic . t - quite mild .  bottle : poured a light pastel color beer with a big foamy head with great retention .  it 's piercing , almost . the nose lands itself squarely on the tongue , unadulterated . what you are left with is a diminished , pale , watery finish . this , fortunately , leads to high quaffability .

aroma : there is a strong smell of malt and hops . the hops has a citrus aroma .  i must admit i was suprised to see this new offering from coopers as i have never heard of it , it pours a pale golden see thru champagne colour with a nice frothy one finger head , sparkling carbonation and bubbly clingy lacing , it has a green , grassy hop aroma with a malty background , it has a thin mouthfeel even thinner for the style for my liking and the taste isnt as pleasant as it looks it has tastes of watery hops with a feint grainish aftertaste not as great as i was hoping for but definately better than the other macro swill out there .  feels thin and watery on the tongue with a low level of carbonation . bitterness is harsh and detracts from drinkability , mouthfeel is unsatisfying , and the flavors are n't interesting and complex enough to yield repeated enjoyment .

the smell was probably what i liked most about this olde style ale .  poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass , beer is what you might expect from a `` black '' beer , very dark in color although not quite black and a root beer colored head .  very little mouthfeel , this beer is meant to be drank ice cold as implied with the cold indicator on the can unlike most beers that i drink .

i 'll first start off by saying this is not at all what i expect from a dubbel , but it 's a beer . smells good , lots of candied sugars up front . very tangy . but to me , it becomes more balanced as i get into it .  poured a dark reddsih-brown . creamy looking head 1 '' high . slightly cloudy .  m : this feels fairly thin ; the flavors fall quickly off the tongue , resulting in a watery finish .
sweet , dark fruit aroma . very sweet , fruity taste .  this beer pours a cloudy amber hue with a thick head that slowly settles .  mouthfeel : lacking . too light for the style .

the smell is of dark fruits . plums , grapes , raisins , and cherries . i tried a `` lift your kilt scottish ale '' from cottonwood at the brewgrass festival and was wondering if this is the same thing .  the appearance is pretty good . it is mostly foam but the head is thick and cloudy and rocky and dense .  very thin feel , little oily .

drinkability : the strong alcohol , of my opinion , does n't go well with the refreshing smell and taste .  the beer pours a nice clear amber color with a small fluffy oatmeal colored head foaming up and fading gradually .  m - slick and watery .

s - the rich caramel and malty nose is unleashed on the pour . a light kiss of hops compliments the very malty nose . smells almost like a dopplebock . very sweet .  solid black body , trails of bubbles run up the sides of the glass , so decent carbonation in this stout . head is khaki and creamy .  very watery .

smell : wine , apples , a light wildness , and a dark malty base .  ap- this beer actually looks pretty damn good sititing in the glass .  mouthfeel was light in body and watery in texture with a flat carbonation .

kinda looks like hopdevil smell - yeast , some hops , mild floral armoa .  pours pale orange amber with hazed clarity . holds a one finger head well after the nitro ceases .  it was flat on the tongue and mouthfeel was very weak .

tomato , oregano , basil , pizza dough , the whole nine yards . i swear i smell green olives ! t : tomato , pepperoni , garlic , olives , dough , even kind of salty . d : let 's face it , you 're going to get this for the same reason i got it : novelty .  bottle : poured a golden color lager with a big foamy head with good retention and some minimal lacing .  the sweetness died out in the taste , however , which was flat and slightly watered-down . a weird bitterness gave an unpleasant mouthfeel but still not difficult to drink .

peachy wine smell , a little apple cider like .  barnyard in a bottle . but uniquely so . if for no other reason than to go back to a differing style .  m - too thin , light body , fizzy carbonation . the mouthfeel on this beer is no good .

smell : sweet roasted malt , vanilla and french oak .  poured a entirely opaque dark brown color that yielded nothing when held up to light . big , creamy tan head that required two pours . lots of lace on the sides of the glass .  m - the downfall of this beer . carbonation is way to high , almost makes the beer feel fuzzy .

the nose is sweet malts with hints of golden fruit and a smattering of spiciness . it'sa shame , too , because i have had some really good beers from green flash ( the double stout is really good .  had at watch city 9/2 reviewed from notes served in a pint glass a : this beer pours a straw yellow with a two finger of creamy head .  mf : thin bodied and only moderate carbonation makes this beer a bit too watery .

the aroma was very sweet and promising with caramel malts being the forerunner .  a careful pour got me a couple fingers of stiff foam over a clear honey colored brew .  palate is watery with that adjuncty grain flavor , but not too offensive . easy drinking .

s : raspberry and lemons with a hint if mint .  a : a strange deep red color with both pink and brownish hues .  i thought that the mouthfeel was kind of watered down ... it needed more `` oommff '' .

deep chocolote , caramel , raison , fig and nuts in the aroma . while i enjoy them , i 'm not a huge fan of irs 's , but if i were to compare to version i do enjoy , like abyss or stone irs , this is not very impressive at all . the mouthfeel is too thin , the bitterness is out of whack , and the beer just comes across unbalanced .  looks nice . has a dark , almost gingerbread like color .  carbonation is minimal , almost flat . again understanding its aged but this beer is pretty sweet and without some degree of carbonation to clear out the palette at the end it becomes cloying .

smells deliciously of currants , but does n't deliver tastewise .  pours a dark copper colour ... . damn good lacing under right conditions ... .smell is of some kind of raspberry extract/cough syrup ( no real fruit aromas ) ... .taste is refreshing .  medium body , almost non existent carbonation , sweet sticky syrupy mouthfeel . i think the lack of carbonation ruins the mouthfeel and makes this taste and smell overly sweet .

pale , cloudy body with little white head that fades quickly s. a cirtusy lemon , banana scent . nice t. sharp zesty taste , leaving a weird lemon aftertaste .  as the blonde approached my table , i noticed the white lace that collared her neck . as as blondes go , she definately deserved a second look , and i obliged . the lavender was so thick i could almost taste it . i needed relief from what looked to be a good encounter but had turned poorly so quickly .  this is a drinkable brew that definatly packs a punch , but it 's kind of one dimensional and thin .
smell : loads of spicy/mint hop aromas , with a casual sweetness on the backend .  served on tap , this pours a pleasing clear amber color .  carbonation is too high .

simple but pleasant .  beer is yellow and completely hazy with a two finger white head of small and medium bubbles that leaves some lacing on the glass .  the mouthfeel is way thin , but drinkability is ok .
there is a nice aroma of oats .  low retention . decent stick .  flavor is good and somewhat spicy , but fades too quickly because body is too thin and watery .

aroma is strongly chocolaty , with a hint of alcohol . taste is a let down after the nice aroma . roasty cold coffee with maybe a smidgeon of bitter chocolate and metallicness .  appearance this one poured a hazy orange in color and was very fluffy just like a good hefe weizen should be .  carbonation is way too strong .

smell is very nice and enticing . t - here 's where this one starts letting me down a bit .  pours out to a clear , deep mahogany , forming a modest light yellow , off-beige head of microbubbles with decent retention and good lacing .  the malt is lightly roasted , but mild with candisugar and syrupy cane sugar . add to that the thin body caused by a lot of sugar and it will add up to a c for me .

my prominent reaction was one of disappointment ; this beer has some nice qualities , most notably a pleasant smell , but lacks much else and has a very flat mouthfeel which really detracted from my enjoyment of this beer and would lead me to not recommend it . aroma is a pleasant sweet coffee smell .  appearance : frothy , mostly diminished head , clear body , brown .  m - watery . too thin , especially for a beer so strong , and meant to be malt-forward .

s : a rich toastiness . the sweetness has a faint caramel that is reminiscent to a lightened wee heavy . d : okay , but really nothing to go crazy about .  slightly hazy amber , with a tan head that foams up and laces .  cloying , sticky raspberry and malty sweetness combine with a major lack of carbonation and a very thin body to achieve complete unbalane in my opinion .

i have never had a pumpkin ale before . it smells of spices ; nutmeg , ginger and clove . it begins deceptively cleanly with a metallic taste before the spices take over with nutmeg to the fore .  i was excited by the color and look .  it 's drinkable , but the body and carbonation are really lacking .

the aroma is pretty nice , with lots of grain , some hay and crackers , a hint of dust and yeasty dough , light earthy-piney hops , hints of sulphur and fruit .  if you just handed this to me i would guess belgian dubbel . really has the belgian aspects right up front just like in the nose ; strong banana and clove , really dominates and considering i expected malt because this is a `` scottish '' i am very dissapointed .  taste is that of a standard belgian wit , but the body was off-puttingly thin . it was watered down , far too light for my tastes of wit beers .
strongly flavoured nose with herbs and nettles .  a - pours a nice clear amber colour with a white large bubbled head that dies quickly to a film .  slightly watery body and bland carbonation .

nose : mulled apple cider . sweet and fruity .  pours out to a clear medium amber with ruby highlights , forming a modest off light yellow head with ok retention and nice sheets of lace .  mouthfeel is very light and watery and it has a similar taste as many other bmc beers , however it does have some light maltiness to it that most macro lagers lack .

smells of overly spiced pumpkin pie , which is a good thing . cinnamon and clove come out straight away . the smell was completely misleading ; i think i found pumpkin in this one somewhere , but the spices are glaringly absent ( with the exception of cinnamon which comes through the nose ) it kind of leaves an off flavor behind that i do n't like .  pours a dark brown with ruby highlights . tan head that fades quickly .  i really like a strong flavor from my beer ... or food for that matter m : watery . with the cloudy , opaque look of this stuff i was expecting ( and hoping for ) a little creamier or more substantial mouthfeel .
the aroma is sweet melon with some grassy , fruity , spicy floral hops .  pretty white head .  this beer is incredibly watery and light on the palate .

s- lots of roasty malt smell , some cocoa t- notes of acrid coffee , black patent , mild hops .  pours a light brass color with very active carbonation . the head has good retention and leaves sticky patches of lace behind .  mouthfeel is lacking as was expected . all in all this one is a step above the macro light brews .
s : strong notes of malt and caramel , sugary smell .  lots of foamy staying head on this lager .  mouthfeel 2/5 mouthfeel got too watery as the beer warmed .

s- grape soda , rasberry jam , sour , fruity lambic . t- hoppy burn but sour . hits back of tounge and washes/settles to the front .  pours a mahogany with a thin beige head .  mouthfeel is thin and watery .

aroma is an intense , lightly parching cherried candy and sweet chocolate , however mildly artificial . cordial cherries dominate the initial flavor , in that sold at the counter , wrapped in red foil , in plastic trays , at a midwestern gas station , kind of way . stout character takes over with a salty and pithy stout run .  pours a deep dark brown , hints of burnt amber in the light .  but the overall mouthfeel is unbalanced , with simply too much fizz against a generally thin texture .

look : orangish in color with a 1/4 head and no retention smell : citrus hops right up front with a hint of caramel and spice in the background taste : this beer is an orange syrupy mess .  nice retention and incredibly solid lace adorns the glass .  carbonation is ridiculously high .

the nose is intensely sour with quite a bit of very strong lactic character and a mild amount of acetic acid . it 's rough , but i enjoyed it . the taste is a different story .  appearance : same great creamy looking head and leaves rings of lace all the way down ... the color is not as black as it used to be , its more of a very dark brown .  the mouthfeel is confusing as it feels too thin for the amount of sweetness on the taste buds .

smells of roasted hopps with mild hints of chocolate .  appearance : pours a super large 3+ finger thinner off-white head . actually poured relatively clear for a dunkelweizen , then quickly turned cloudy after a few seconds .  thin and tingly mouthfeel .

very warm and quite appealing with a nice strength . warming , soothing , and well spiced . nothing jumps out at ya really , its a great medley of nutmeg , cinnamon , brown sugar , and pumpkin .  mythos from greece : a hellenic lager , in a 11.5 ounce green bottle . strong euro-skunk aroma . thick white head , long lasting , with pronounced belgian lace . light bodied , deep golden color .  seemed flat and had a flat taste .

a : pours dark brown with purple hue , has a cloudy appearance ... similar to dark chocolate milk . s : nose features rich roasted malta along with candied red grapes .  bottle : poured a slightly hazy blonde color ale with a huge foamy head with better then average retention .  biting carbonation , was that a hint of roastiness ?

aroma : strong but nice lemon wheat aroma . the aroma was nice but it goes downwards after that .  labeled scaldis , pours a nice brown amber with a huge head that stays throughout drinking the beer .  chocolately , dark . dry chalky taste , sweet . some warming . watery porter-like .

nice . the taste starts out pretty good .  a= the pour is a nice deep golden color with a crispy white head on it that holds some decent retention and lacing .  taste : carbonated water , with hops and light malt thrown in . mouthfeel : light and quickly fading .

the nose was dominated by well fired malts , dried & roasted figs and molasses . plenty of fragrance .  a- deep dark browen/black . light tan head . i think that they literally dumped vanilla extract into this beer once it finished fermenting .  mouthfeel very flat for a belgian dubbel .

good fruity aroma upon opening the bottle .  looks like a nice beer .  mouthfeel is kind of thin and not very pleasant as the carbonation dies down and leaves a sort of flat cola sensation , without the stickiness .
it 's a great aroma , but little else needs to be said .  has a pretty nice look actually .  m - maybe i 've had too many rises recently , but this is thin , very very thin .

smelled pretty good , hops & grain filled the nose immediately . after sitting for a moment , the smell faded slightly , but still nice . tasted some hops , but not nearly as dominant as i prefer .  appearance - a murky , dirty orange wth a certain luminescence to it . a nice cap builds up to about a finger 's depth , off white , creamy with pocky dimples . the head hangs around a bit , displaying some lace as it yields .  mouthfeel is thin and a bit watery .

smells bright and interesting . t - what a letdown .  12 oz bottle poured into a pilsner - fridge - 2009 appearance : pours a transparent golden color with lots of flowing carbonation . the head is white and rises 1 '' tall , showing a good amount of foaminess and retention . a coating of lace remains behind . nice !  mouthfeel : this is where the beer went south for me . the carbonation was almost non-existent , which was in stark contrast to the initial appearance .

not a big fan of this one , but it 's drinkable . i expect more of a fruit profile if the fruit is in the name . sweet and low bitterness , perhaps a bit too sweet .  appearance this one had a nicely carbonated orange body with some cool-looking sediment and a promising head .  nose : it 's aroma is a little bit malty , a little bit citrusy flavor : the taste has some lemon/citrus notes w/ some hints of maltiness , but the big thing that you notice is how fizzy this beer is . it 's far too fizzy for me .
nose is full of pumpkin pie spices with a strong presence of ginger and nutmeg .  a-tan and spongy head with a black body .  mouthfeel is way watery and i feel like it is slightly udnercarbonated .

this smells of ipa and initially it tastes of ipa with strong pink grapefruit and copper malt backbone ... but then there 's a little bite of fake-fruity-artificialsweetness ... reminds me of leiny 's sunset wheat ... almost like somebody dropped a shot of that in here ... which is not a good thing ... it really hits in the aftertaste and really turns me in the wrong direction on this beer ... i give it props for the taste up front ... and for the fact that it completely hides it 's alcohol content ... in that aspect i 'm not sure if i 've ever had a 7 % 'er that did n't have some alcohol bite ... but that off-put-taste of fake sweetener is just turning me off of this one and it will be my last .  appearance - golden yellow , very carbonated , very pretty -- looks appetizing .  mouthfeel : way too carbonated .

nice . the aroma is quite nice , but the taste reminds me of when i 've experimented with adding bourbon to other stouts and accidentally added too much .  i know there are tons of people who rave about guinness ... but for what reason , i do n't know ... a : bartender did not perfect pour this one for sure , but it still looked good s : smells like burnt coffee t : tastes like it smells , burnt coffee m : like cold burnt thick coffee .  almost watery .

nose is dark malt with some nice subtle estery notes of banana , raisin and pear .  bad sign , but i ordered it anyway a - looked fine , medium golden , mildly hazy s - mild citric hop smell quickly hidden behind malty/bisquity sweet smell . can still smell the yeast on it as well , which makes me wonder if they filter at all .  thin and watery for a dark beer . little carbonation . needless to say , i was disapointed in this beer .

deep brown color ... .i really like the nose ... .definite cocoa and a slight hit of cherries ... the nose is top notch but it goes down the tubes from there ... a tart/sour flavor overwhelmes this..perhaps it 's the cherries ... a soft chocloate flavor is a slightly noticable underlying flavor ... .  a - foggy tea-color , with an ample tan head .  m : watery , high carbonation .

very pungent and filling . however , it 's surprisingly malty , more than both ramnuts and i cared for .  poured a nice garnet hue with a slight off white head that barely lingers with minamal lacing going on .  it does bring vanilla to mind . the sweetness almost removes it from the style of beer . far to thin for a brown ale .

a hint of cinnamon mixes in there that is a bit unique fir the style t - taste is banana with a hint of bubblegum ; bit of malty sweetness dominates the flavor with a hint of oak of the end ; bit sweet for my taste and much sweeter than the noise led on to mf - bit thick with a hint of syrup ; light carbonation on the back end that attempts to break down some of the sweet , stickiness of the beer but fails d - happy this was a one off since that is about the only time i would drink it .  a : the pour is dark amber/red-brown with a thin tan head forming .  the mouthfeel is the downfall , it is watery with a dry finish , it just does n't convey the flavors to the tongue well enough .

the aroma seems to be pretty good , nice strong malt scent that gives off the idea of caramel also giving a sweet smell .  almost opaque black with deep ruby highlights . nice creamy tan head looks like nitro to me .  the herbal hops will become medicinal with traces of alluminum and will become a bit less appealing as it goes from a zippy feel to rather stagnent . a flat and bitter hop flavor is the finish .

has a unique floral-like almost medicinal band-aid brett character to it . a different aroma , but an intriguing one . ( t ) - very different from the smell . very dry and bitter with tons of clay . a bit disjointed and surprisingly thin even for the style .  a pretty golden orange color in the glass but the fragrance was musty to me and actually unpleasant .  far too thin and light for a bock . carbonation was assertive , but the body just felt thin and watery .

the aromas are loaded with dank hop earthiness and woodiness from the oak aging . defintely also some citrus/pine and the alcohol notes finish out the smells . the tastes are good , with apple brandy-like alcohol that is hot on the tongue right off the bat , but this one is too syprupy for me . the oak is there , but not in a good way , and the thickness/syrup qualities , detract from the hops .  famous november 2003 750ml : nice orange-brown color . thin off-white head .  however , extremely thin for a beer , and not very carbonated either .

while this beer was pretty much a by-the-books saison , it does n't seem to make much sense to not even give this beer some kind of hops characteristic or impart some small signature that we have come to know and love lagunitas for . basically , this bomber is an orthodox , nice saison , that hits all of the right flavors on the nose but is disappointing overall -- mild , thin , bland in color and not complex .  appearance : looks pretty good .  mouthfeel is extremely thin- it felt like a porter rather than an ris .

there is a very nice fruity sweet character along with an inviting spiceyness in the aroma . the flavor is sour , dry and reminds me of fruit going bad .  appearance : pours a brilliant copper in color , extremely clear with a ton of carbonation bubbles ( not necessarily a good thing ) .  mouthfeel is flat and thin . medium bodied and watery in texture , this brew falls short of anything special on the palate .

even before i finished pouring the glass my nose was overwhelmed with dark cherry aromas that almost made my mouth water . the smell was deep and lustrous , with only the slightest hint that i was holding a beer . the dense red cap of bubbles refused to break apart as i swirled the beer around to release more of that luxurious cherry smell . the beer is dark red through and through .  pours a blackish brown with maybe three fingers of puffy tan head .  tingly , thin watery feel .

looks like maple syrup i think . some grape , plums , burnt caremel perhaps . taste- not like the smell at all . sour at first .  bottle into a pint glass pours black in color with a bit of red highlighting along the edges of the glass .  mouthfeel was poor .

the nose comprises lemon zest , a light funk , cardamom , hay , and mandarin oranges .  thanks to kegatron for the extras ! a-golden kissed copper with a fluffy white head that hung on , slowly reduced and left decent lace .  mouthfeel : the carbonation is very high , way too high , for a milk stout . the body is thin . drinkability : just an ok beer , the mouthfeel also hurts the drinkability .

s- lots of coffee , and *tons* of that smoky flavor you 'd expect from the title . i actually ... do n't like the way they jive as much as i thought i would , but it 's still nice . t- this is actually ... kind of disgusting . very nice d- not a fan .  big , black , thick and sludgy looking . nice looking half a finger of leather head . some visual spotty lacing .  mouthfeel is very thin and weak .

amber color with a huge orangey , frothy head that leaves crusty peaks like meringue as it dissipates . aroma is of hop , citrus , and pine .  looks great on a bar top . amber red with a decent enough head but little retention , surprised to see some good lacings .  the weak malt presence and light flavor really hasnt enough oomph to fire up the taste buds . this one lacks that definitive crisp and bitter roastiness of the traditional dry stout . or watering their beers down ? actually , this wasnt that bad - light , thin and watered down , but not terrible .
s- very tart sour smell . bit like figs or sour apple .  nice head and appearance .  mouthfeel is all wrong . way too much carbonation and way too thin of a body .

s : sweet and fruity , raisiny , red wine-iness comes through , though this is definitely beer as it has a strong malt character , roastiness and spicy hops . t : a sweet flavor up front with an off , flavor blocking presence in the center of my tongue ( wacky and tannic ) .  pours a color similiar to my girlfriends hair color . good head and retention though .  the mouthfeel was a bit thin and watery .

the aroma has a very nice citrousy hopness to it with a good grainy scent in the background .  pours out to a clear ( i.e-filtered ) pale golden , forming a tall , poofy white head with excellent retention and nice lacing .  m : mild , almost weak or watery . does not have stout presence at all ; feels like flat cola , if anything .

the smell is a strong lime zest aroma from the outset , with some lime and lemon aromas and a bit of malt aroma beneath .  pours a clear bright copper with a tall white frothy head .  mouthfeel - super watery overall - the only thing this beer has going for it is the aroma which is misleading .
the smell is defiantly banana bread , a welcoming aroma .  appearance : rich amber color , with about one finger 's worth of head .  as many others have said , i 'm not liking the extra carbonation .

the aroma is powerful with the start anise and burbon really dominating , a hint ot the orange came out , but after tasting , all i could smell was the bourdon and black licorice flavor ( start anise ) . to me the bourbon overpowers the rest of the beer , so if you 're more of a bourbon drinker , this would be right up your alley .  pours a dark , fairly thick , muddy brown with a thin beige head . good head retention . given my memory of the pale , winter , and scandia , this is definitely one of their weaker offerings .  taste : decidedly like its nose , only more so ; large notes of bittersweet chocolate and espresso rule the roost , here ; not nearly as sweet as you might imagine ; total lack of carbonation left the impression of a somewhat light , thin mouthfeel .

looked nice and had a nice aroma to it , but i just never got into it .  nitro like creamy in texture and tan like color head in appearance . some good lacing while drinking also . bouquet is dead for an oatmeal stout , not much going here .  it is very thin like any us macro , making it very drinkable like water .

the beer smells mostly of semi-sweet dark chocolate and is quite nice .  nice auburn with yellow highlights .  `` simple '' is the best word i can use to describe the taste , but it does deliver with scorched malts with a touch of lactose . my biggest complaint with this beer is the mouthfeel- it 's way too watery .

nose is slightly spicy with hints of witbier style coriander seed , matched with a sticky-sweet hint of dark toffee and brown sugar . it 's actually rather pleasant all up , and certainly gives a deeper note than expected from the lightness in the body and the colour .  poured slightly heady with a very cloudly light brown color .  slightly watery body with adequate carbonation . mouthfeel is slick and thin with a metallic and astringent finish as it dries .

( s ) - slight dry paleness with a sweet lemon , honey , and biscuity wheat characteristics . bits of clay & yeast behind some minimal pine coming through on the finish . ( t ) - really dry and bitter pine that overpowers some ( from what i can tell ) biscuits and banana with a twist of clove ; but it is hard to tell .  it poured a deep , cherry red with minimal head which foamed a bit when swirled .  heard great things about this , found it in buffalo bought a 96 vintage.started promising i liked the color and the nice head , after that all downhill.had little to no smell , the taste was peppery ( overpoweringly so ) and way to sour ! the beer was way to thin and watery to go along with that taste.didnt finish the bottle just to peppery and thin for me , waiste of six bucks .

the aroma is nice and sweet , but that 's about all this has going for it .  pours a nutty brown ( not a golden brown ! ) with a big , soapy light beige head with good retention and generous lacing . a lagerish wimp that masks as a dunkel - if you compare it to kstritzer schwarzbier , or even krusovice , it comes across as half-baked and undernourished .  the flavor echoes the aroma , but the mouthfeel is n't quite up to scratch - weirdly thin and watery , which does no favors to the toasty , nutty , tea-like , and hoppy notes that are all individually assertive but harmonious and balanced in tandem , like a good jazz band .

flowery aroma , malty & hoppy but very flowery .  poured from bottle into a pint glass a : dark brown coloring , fairly subtle tan-colored head .  thin mouthfeel with average macro carbonation . touch of caustic mouthfeel in the middle with the bitterness and petrol notes .

smells surprisingly thick : notes of chocolate on apricot and hops .  appearance- black with little tan head .  the mouthfeel needs work . it is n't creamy at all , it is just really watery and lacking carbonation .

a full white head of three fingers , over one finger hangs for awhile , good lacing ... the aroma is pretty nice , lots of clove and wheat , sweet and nice , surprised ... the taste is not good at all , the clove turns in banana vodka , harsh , alcoholic , astringent , not good .  this filled the pint glass with a densely black color with a little red at the edges .  mouthfeel : thin and watery body , medium carbonation overall : highly overrated .
aroma is quite solid , lots of passion fruit and light citrus mixed with belgian sugars .  deep cherrywood or chestnut body with white fluffy head .  fizzy carbonation and no body .

yep , it 's a black beer . it started well with a nice head and aroma . sweet fruit and coffee flavors , not too heavy .  pours a golden color with a big head .  mouthfeel is very watery w/ average crabonation .

the smell is apples , vanilla , peppers , and caramel . it has some almost witbeer-like characteristics .  beautiful deep plum color , purpley and dark with a small off-white head that vanished quickly , leaving whispers of thin micro-bubbles and a tiny ring around the collar .  t- vanilla/cream soda , one-dimensional caramel malt . very vanilla . m- mouth is unrefined and rough in the way i would expect from good ol bmc . sweetness lingers in an unpleasant and sticky way .

woody roast malt aroma with wet earth , chocolate and other goodies .  pours a cherry-tinged hazy and opaque amber , but mostly cherry , with decent carbonation and a perfectly white head that thins to a collar .  m- thin and watery this could be improved greatly , but then it would probably be too sweet .

smells of wheat , banana ( among other fruity aromas ) , cloves and other pepper-like spices . appearance and aroma were right on for the style but the taste was lacking a bit .  a - amber in color , nice head , pretty good lace that lasted until the very last drop .  the first part of the taste it quite strong and somewhat acidic but as you move to the middle and rear of your mouth the beer becomes very thin .

the nose is pleasant . nice spice .  pours completely pitch black this beer consumes all visible light spectrums emitted , large tan head viable forming a robust carbonation and honorable smell .  for a russian imperial this is even for 9.7 incredibly weak and watery it 's the first thing i notice . the mouthfeel on this is not good , it 's even weaker than most american stouts i 've had .

smell was sweet cherries , dark . toffee .  beer pours a very nice hazy light amber color with a nice but not lingering white head .  it 's also crisp . for a beer that looked so terrible ( albeit , it was dark ) and had such a poor mouthfeel , it sure tasted good .

smell is sweet molases , carmel , and the like . the taste is ... meh .  appearance - surprisingly though , this cheap beer looked great ! thick bubbly foam , golden , opaque color , and great looking carbonation made this one appealing from the get-go .  carbonation appears low . beer is thin and boring , not much there at all . mild sweetness very water like . bummer .
smell : lots and lots of blueberries .  a : clear golden color with a medium sized white head . a pretty lively beer , lots of ascending bubbles .  it was very thin bodied as well .

the smell is quite inviting . taste is slightly bitter .  a : pours an extremely dark brown with a little bit of light passage when the glass is held to a lamp . there is about a 1 finger creamy looking head with decent retention and some lacing .  m surprisingly watery for the body ; slightly carbonated with a light , watery finish . my major complaint is with the mouthfeel , the watery texture really detracts from its drinkability in my book .

lots of lacing . smell : big vanilla and caramel with a slight hint of roasted malt . i was ready for sweet , but this is easily the sweetest beer ive ever had .  once things settled down , the presentation was nice , with a foamy tan head that left lots of lace over a very cloudy reddish-brown brew .  mouthfeel is flat but this is the only disappointment .

disappointed , as i am an avid stone fan and this being my first opportunity with the levitation ale . while the prose was sweet as ever , the brew itself was exceedingly oppressive , strongly hopped -- i would hands down prefer ruination to levitation when it comes to high hops from stone .  i poured into a pint glass to a half inch of light tan head .  mf : too smooth and wet . watery even , but not creamy .

aroma is earthy , piney hops , maybe simcoe , balanced quite nicely with a bready malt backbone .  a - clear light amber pour with a nice light one finger pour that results in very gentle lacing .  the palate is thin .
